number of helpful: 132 of 230 people (57%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 1, 2014
Minor Note: This account has ~40 hours played because I didn't have family sharing before this review. INTRO / SUMMARYThe focus of this review is to explain the horror aspect of the game since an incomplete playthrough leaves me unable to adequately analyze anything else.The goal of this survival horror is to scare the player. Amnesia: The Dark Descent was not scary enough to keep my interest to finish the game. I kept playing to try and finish it all in one sitting, however, I stopped after 9 hours because I realized Amnesia was just not my kind of horror.  On a good note, it did stray away from the action and guns-blazing direction that some horror series seem to be going down. Of course, not everyone has the same idea of horror so I’ll further elaborate in the next sections to help anyone who may be indecisive…Pros:+ Some interesting grotesque designs and haunting atmosphere+ Impressive graphics, lighting and physics+ Great immersive soundtrackCons:- Not many scary moments- Tedious, repetitive and predictable- Lacks the “struggle aspect” in survival horror (in terms of game-play, for the PLAYER)- Daniel’s reactions took away from the experience (and made me feel like the bigger man)“WILL IT BE SCARY FOR ME?”[Not Recommended] If you…  Believe that being startled or nervous is not the equivalent to being scared. Prefer horror titles to include a game-play challenge to stay alive (e.g. careful management, risk vs reward, fight vs flight decisions, etc). Usually figure out the “formula” or “pattern” in video games. (This may remove the immersion and dampen the horror for you.) Think that keeping the protagonist calm and from fainting sounds like babysitting rather than a sanity mechanic. [Recommended]If you…  Prefer a "casual" or “theme park” sense of horror where the emphasis is on exploration, imagery and atmosphere. Believe the aesthetic presentation is more important than game-play to make an effective horror title (e.g. imagery, sounds, visual design, etc.). Agree that challenging game-play makes a horror title frustrating rather than scary or it is not preferred.   Don’t get tired from playing a cat and mouse game for 9+ hours. Like H.P. Lovecraft inspired themes and/or psychological horror.THE SCARY FACTOR - FURTHER ANALYSISThe game attempts to provide a horror experience through atmosphere based on the fear of what cannot be seen (in the wait of physical danger), psychological horror (hence "amnesia" and the horrors uncovered from the protagonist's psyche), imagery to disturb the player, very few jump-scares, and providing the feeling of defenselessness by having no weapon option. My experience, however, lacked horror most of the time because the game’s predictability allowed me to be confident in my ability to run and hide rather than testing my courage or facing my fears head-on. For the most part you walk around, collect stuff, solve a puzzle, run from easy enemy AI, hide, and repeat. I was able to figure out the pattern of the game early; I knew that for the most part I was safe, had a good idea on what would trigger the encounters and what to do when that happened. I was prepared and ready. -Because of this, most of the game felt like filler for the sake of having a pattern or to make the game longer. I would have preferred a short game compressed of clever horror events (such as evolving the mechanics) rather than a drawn out experience of the same thing repeated.Another problem was that this game didn't have the sense of struggle that survival horror usually provides to accomplish horror. Amnesia’s experience felt effortless to succeed compared to other survival horror titles I've played (e.g. Silent Hill, Resident Evil, Rule of Rose, etc.); as a result, I never felt in any real danger. There weren't any good portrayals of careful management of resources, a high risk vs. reward or anything like that. Limited lamp oil was a good start, but the 60 tinderboxes (cylinders?) in my inventory were too large of a safety net. The sanity meter was another attempt to make you manage your light sources, but Daniel’s reaction to everything that happens takes away from the experience. He’ll gasp, breathe heavily and faint to indicate his lowering sanity from occurrences; as a result, I got annoyed and couldn't help but to roll my eyes at the fact the game had to point out what’s “scary” through Daniel.Although there were some moments I did like (no spoilers, just vague descriptions). The water level and prison hallways provided a different change of pace. The water part was a good example on how the game-play could be dynamic, yet still use the same simple mechanics in order to provide uncertainty and invade the player’s comfort without the use of combat or completely seeing the enemy. The prison hallways provided a claustrophobic feeling in the narrow hallways with a great contrast between the vulnerability of the unknown within the darkness and the exposure to be seen in the light. There were no “obvious” hiding places, such as a closet, instead you had to rely on anything you could in your environment, (e.g. dark corner, hiding behind furniture etc.) which made the fear and game-play feel more “natural” in these sections.

												What makes "Amnesia: The Dark Descent" so scary and spooky is the environment combined with sinister background music that changes depending on your mental state. Playing around with the physics of almost any object ingame is one of the main features in this game and I enjoy it quite a lot. You can't fight back in this game but you can hide and block doors with any moveable objects. There is also a bonus chapter which is pretty well done imo.If you ever manage to complete the game you can try out some custom stories from the community. There are quite a lot of them and some of them are scary as hell... Your journey to the dark site has just begun my friend!

number of helpful: 11 of 11 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 16, 2016
												A genuinely great and unique game. It’s a bit of a milestone in gaming history because most horror games after it had some sort of feature or aspect that was from amnesia which is awesome. This was my second playthrough since I first played it back at release and I didn’t find it very scary this time, probably because I remembered all the scary moments because the game is so memorable. The fact that I remembered so much about the game since I first played it almost 6 years ago is crazy, it just shows the quality of the scares and the level design in particular. Very good atmosphere and sound design, it’s a very loud game with headphones compared to other games with the same volume level. Pretty interesting story for what is, very simple and creepy and it works nicely. I particularly like the ending. The puzzles are very challenging and clever but sometimes the solutions are very vague, I had to look up a few times what to do with mixed reactions after. Sometimes I felt like an idiot for not being able to figure it out but there were a few objects to pick up or interact with where I thought ‘I would never have found that myself’. This is a bit of a gripe, most times you encounter an enemy its mainly for a distance and all you have to do is just hide for a second and they go away which is part of why I didn’t find the game scary anymore. If the monster actually went and chased you in those situations It would have worked better. But even then when I was getting chased by an enemy I usually let them kill me straight away just so they could go away and they don’t spawn again in the same area where you died the next time which I consider a bit of a design flaw especially after just recently playing alien isolation with the manually saving. I also just recently played a lot of horror games that I found scarier than amnesia and I’m sure it’s mostly because it was my second playthrough. I think this is a must play if you haven’t played it yet.  8/10 (Great)

												I must say, this game is REALLY scary. And I mean it. I remember when this game came and peolple were like: "This is too scary, I can't play it more than couple of minutes" or "I'm gonna never play this game again". I've been playing the orginal story trough and before it I had watched many gameplays and walktrhougs from it. Even after them I was really afraid when I played it. I knowed well enough where monsters appears, but nevertheless they scared me.The basic idea of the game is survive in dark castle and escape from monsters. You can't fight to monsters, you can only escape or hide. You must also collect the pages of your diary, because you haven't memories from past. Them tell you about the story. The game isn't just running and hiding. There's also many puzzles what give such good a change.It's not just scare because of terrible and ugly monsters (sometimes it's even quite funny to play with them), the real horror is made by absolutely great atmosphere. And what make this atmosphere, they are sounds and musics. Firstly I must praise musics. From peaceful and mystical ambiences to terrible and oppressive themes. In different places you hear variable musics and also every events and monsters have it's own themes.The storytelling is made by foundable diary pages and sounds what you here in flashbacks. I'm such glad that there isn't very much violence in the game, but the sounds you sometimes hear in the flashbacks will be disturbing. A whole sound of world is very well carry out. Also the great story and scare places create good atmosphere.Bad in this game is sometimes quite bad bugs and shortness, but you can download other palyers enlargements from net.Buy this game, it's great!

content:
Posted: December 29, 2016
												This game is not one of those all "hype" and no "show", it will drain your guts dry as it is one of the scariest horror game there is. You play as Daniel, a Londoner who just experienced a terrible "amnesia" and woke up on the floor of a big mansion, armed with nothing at all but cinder boxes and a lantern to lit the darkness where the fiend of the mansion may hide and stalk your back. Reminded me of how a survival horror game should be, Amnesia: The Dark Descent is really the ultimate interactive horror software that horror mongers should enjoy, with a good and deep story telling keeping you tense on the edge of the seat on most of the playtime. The sanity feature really gives an identity to the game, as no game before this has it. Will you prowl in the dark hiding from the "residents" of the mansion stealthily and go nuts, or lit everything that can be with the risk of being seen but stay sane? Definitely a must buy for the true fans of the amazing genre survival horror that is.

content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												An old classic horror game that changed the history of the horror genre and youtube. Amnesia the Dark Descent. is a first-person horror game, where you play as Daniel, who seems to have drank an potion that gave him anmesia. it's your job to venture into the darkness and solve the reason behind of own actions and find the man who seems to be the reason behind all this.In Amnesia the Dark Descent you must advance in the game, solve puzzles and avoid being seen by the monsters. You have no weapons or any ways of defending yourself, so you must hide, or run if necessary. Unlike other horror games, Amnesia has a sanity meter, which slowly drains if you are in darkness, if you look at the monsters or see unexpected events. if it get's too low. your screen will start to shake, nearby evironment may change and the monsters might find you easier. Amnesia the Dark Descent should not be played to win. but to be played for the exprience. it's called the "king of horror" by gamers for a reason. and i'll hugely recommend this game to every horror game lover and to those who wants to try a spooky game.

number of helpful: 12 of 14 people (86%) found this review helpful4 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 25, 2016
Product received for free
												We're currently going through an age where the horror genre is dying out as they're getting repetitive, at least for horror games that occupy the Steam market and Steam Greenlight. However, when people thought that there was no hope, Amnesia: The Dark Descent decided to come on in and show everybody how a horror game should be done.In Amnesia: The Dark Descent, the main thing that makes it a truly great horror experience is the fact that it makes you defenseless as you have nothing to defend yourself against the horrors that may lie inside the castle. All you have is your trusty oil lantern, which keeps on running out of oil and forces you to find more. Your only way of truly escaping these monsters is to hide from them by using the darkness and the hiding places to your advantage. However, if you spend too long in the darkenss, it can affect your sanity, so you can't spend too long in the darkness. This is a great way to experience true horror, making you feel defenceless against the monsters that litter the castle, that are rigorously trying to hunt you down. It's rare you feel this sort of way in horror games nowadays, which is why it's so refreshing to see it being taken into effect in this game. There are also some puzzles that are thrown at the player, none of these puzzles are difficult per say as long as you've been paying attention to the notes and hints that have been left around for you, however some of these puzzles feel a bit tedious and unnecessary to add in.The story of Amnesia is that you play as Daniel who has woken in the castle with no recolection of anything at all, you as the player must tread through the castle, picking up notes, piecing back together Daniel's memory, avoiding the enemies around the castle and foiling a maniacal scheme that is set to be carried out. I always like the sort of games that throw this sort of plot at the player because it makes you feel immersedin the role as the main character knows as much as the player does and he learns along with the player. However besides the set up of it, the rest of the plot doesn't feel that special and, I'm not going to revela spoilers here or anything, but by the time I reached the end of the game, I fealt like I had more questions than answers and for the last 20 minutes, due to the story, I fealt like I wasn't really playing the game I thought I was going to be playing when I first started it up, if you know what I mean.This is an indie development company and I was amazed by the graphics when the game started. They went into lots of detail when designing the game. The lighting work that is done on the windows of the castle is great, the walls look really god and detailed, even the monster look quite good. The only complaint I have is that some of the creatures that scatter across the ground at times look like they were made of an ugly blob, but that's just nitpicking.The sound in this game is brilliant. The noises that occupy the castle sound terrifyingly real, especially with headphones, it really helps you immerse yourself in the world that this game is creating.I really enjoyed my time with Amnesia: The Dark Descent as it took risks that other horror games dare not take and did it with a terrific pay offPros+ Terrifying+ Good gameplay elements+ Good graphics+ Great sounds+ Pretty good storyCons- Tedious puzzles- Got a bit sci-fi near the endFinal verdict: 9/10My Steam curator group: http://steamcommunity.com/groups/MellowReviews

												I played Amnesia for 11 hours and i enjoyed every single moment of this game. It's full of dark places, your light is limited, and there are monsters around you, which you can only free from. The lack of light makes you feel scared and insecure, expecially for your "brain health": if there's no sufficient light or if you are looking to a monster for too much time, the brain health will go down and strange visions and effects will appear on the screen. I think it's one of the best aspects of this game. The sound has a great quality as well, making you feel inside the game, and there are many puzzles and hard parts that will keep your brain working for long time. I advice for sure this game to the horror fans, and i advice to the others to try it out, cause it really deserves a lot.

 Amnesia: The Dark Descent  Production of the creators of Penumbra. This is the adventure survival horror, tells the story of Daniel, who has lost his memory on its own initiative and now wanders basements, hallways and and other parts of the huge castle discovering the horrific events of his past and struggle to survive. The game is about exploration but also in our way will be a puzzles to solve. He is not able to defend themselves against the monsters so our goal is to avoid contact with them, hiding, avoiding the dark but also taking care of the health and psychological status of our hero. The game is one of the best survival horrors I've ever played, dark and gloomy atmosphere, great sound system, the monsters that always will give you creeps, taking care not to run out of oil lamp. In addition there is the ability to play the new campaigns created by players. If you're a fan of such a games I would definitely recommend this production.

content:
Posted: February 21
												Story: The story follows Daniel, a fellow from London who awakes in Brennenburg Castle with amnesia. The game tells the story primarily through audio flashbacks Daniel has while exploring the castle. These flashbacks along with notes you can find inform you of your past. Through these notes your past self directs you to the inner sanctum where you must kill a man named Alexander. Past Daniel also mentions a shadow that follows you relentlessly and cannot be stopped. Amnesia’s primary story and message is found in these flashbacks and journals, here you’ll learn why Daniel has no memories, why you wanted to kill Alexander, and what the shadow is. A major theme of Amnesia is morality and it is primarily studied through Daniel’s actions before he lost his memory. Without spoiling the major plot points, the game does a great job of putting the player into a state of mind and position where they can weigh the moral decisions made by their player character Daniel and not feel a great dissonance. That is important as the moral dilemmas Daniel faced are another whole terrifying aspect of Amnesia. This being said, the story and past events add to the suffocating and tension-filled atmosphere. The story and atmosphere prop each other, each benefitting from the others consistent delivery. The story of Amnesia is not brilliant or revolutionary but it does plague the character with the dark realities of his past, in turn adding to what is truly exceptional about Amnesia, its atmosphere.Atmosphere: The setting of Amnesia is Brennenburg Castle, a dark, crumbling castle somewhere in Prussia. This setting is a truly perfect fit for the gameplay and story. The castles interior is eerie, wet, falling into ruin, and mysterious. The interior design of the castle is pretty standard stuff for the most part, with your archives, cellars and such. Although standard, the aesthetics and sounds combined with just enough mystery and dark influences make the game very original in execution, especially for a video game. Nearly the entire game takes place inside the castle, as you dive into its bowels. Only for a moment do you step outside. This moment was pretty cool too. For me it provided some real context and sense of where I was in the world, even if I only saw a vast dark forest. Something about seeing what surrounded the castle added another layer to the isolation and overbearing darkness of the atmosphere. All this darkness and weightiness of the atmosphere becomes suffocating and nearly a deterrent to continuing the game. Luckily, there are skillfully placed hub areas that provide a much needed contrast to the claustrophobic, monster inhabited areas. These hub areas take a weight off your chest by providing just enough light and calming sounds. That leads me to the sound design, which truly amplifies the feelings of suffocation, claustrophobia, and ultimately terror. The sound effects pick and gnaw at you, with sounds of rats, insects, and the unknown. Meanwhile the soundtrack provides a deep, trembling groan that is ever-present. Sounds like grinding or cavernous echoes ebb in and out seamlessly. That is the greatness of this sound design, it is seamlessly bound to the atmosphere and gameplay. This effectively immerses the player entirely in the game world. Aside from the main menu, there is no remarkable track that you’ll recall afterwards. You’ll only be left with the feelings that sounds and visuals provided you.Gameplay: The gameplay of Amnesia is fairly simple but deep in its applications. The way you’re able to interact with objects physically is satisfying and intuitive. This is primarily implemented in three scenarios: searching for items, solving puzzles, and hiding from/blocking monsters. While moving through the game, the physics engine really connects you to the game. I see this as a huge benefit in a game where you’re banking on becoming immersed. Using environmental objects to solve puzzles makes the puzzles see less contrived and more natural for the situation. Using wardrobes and stacking barrels to hide for monsters really throws you into the world, giving you a fantastic physical sense of the game. This mechanic adds serious depth to gameplay that isn’t up in your face. The moments when you come across a monster for the first few times, the game leaves you feeling helpless and overwhelmed in terror. It takes you a second to think of what you can do. Then you realize you must push on, so hiding and running often are a temporary solution. In all, the monsters and their encounters are well designed and used sparingly as to not reveal too much.Your inventory stores a few essential items along with puzzle items. You’re also able to craft here, although crafting is not a big component of the game. This interface also houses your sanity status. Sanity in Amnesia is a crucial mechanic that pits the player against a rock and a hard place. The idea is that you lose sanity in the dark but while you in the light you’re easily seen by monsters. It’s a mechanic the whole game rests on to keep the player on their toes. An aspect that ties into sanity is solving puzzles. Puzzles will boost your sanity when solved and holy crap is this an effective way to encourage the push on! The satisfaction from completing puzzles is really felt by the player, as a wave of relief rushes over you. Overall, I must say I love the gameplay here. It takes a step back to let the atmosphere do its work, while bolstering the players’ connection to the game world.Overall: Since the release of Amnesia, its formula has been reused several times with some games reaching larger audiences. I’d recommend this game to anyone who wants a first-person horror experience. If you’re someone who has played any of Amnesia’s contemporaries and influenced works and enjoyed it, this game is well worth your time. From the outside looking in the game may look outdated or silly/cliché. Amnesia will prove these notions wrong as I have not come across a game more terrifying and immersive. This game is an example that graphical fidelity is not all important if you have excellent game and world design.

number of helpful: 7 of 7 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 24, 2016
												Into the lightI’m not normally a fan of games that present you with deadly enemies and then give you no option to defend yourself, but ATDD uses this device cautiously and to good effect. Evading the enemies is fairly stressful (as it should be) but is never frustrating or annoying. ATDD is all about atmosphere, which it has by the bucketload, and story, which it has in some depth. Much of what has to be done in the game, by way of solving puzzles, will be familiar to anyone who has played adventure games before but here again ATDD gets the formula just right. This is the first survival horror game I’ve played that has no combat (I’ve played plenty that do) and I was pleasantly surprised at how well it performs in both the survival and the horror aspects. Graphically it’s pretty good but not outstanding. There are some nice touches of interactivity: you have to pull and push at doors and drawers in order to open and close them. And the sound design is also very atmospheric. It’s a fairly short game but it packs quite a lot into 10–15 hours of gameplay and is recommended if you like the horror genre. 4/5

content:
Posted: February 27, 2013
												The creepy Lovecraftian atmosphere of the darkened halls of Brennenburg Castle and the disturbing entities within will scare you down to your core. You have no weapons to defend yourself from the lurking creatures. You can only put temporary obstacles in front of them or run away and hide in the dark, but not for too long before you start to lose your sanity, which makes you even more vulnerable to attacks, although you can always light your path with your lamp and torches.Amnesia: The Dark Descent is an unsettling and uncanny experience: storyline told in the form of memories and diary pages, spooky visuals, a fair amount of physics-based puzzles, tense moments and spine-chilling sound effects that will put your nerves to the test.

												This is one hell of a creepy game! And this is no lie!At the beginning it is slow and somekind of a bit moody. But if you let yourself drawn in by its atmosphere it will haunt you. At least at that fricking waterfilled basement!In the end I ripped my headphones off my ears and paused that damn game. First time such thing ever happened to me. The gameplay mechanics are well-thought; you can't defeat monsters with a arsenal of weapons and amusengly high amounts of ammunition. You can only hide from them and hope they won't see you. Very nice: Enemies will detect you if you stare at them. This leads to situation where you facing a wall and hoping this creature will leave the room already without detecting you. Very nice, to be remembered what it is to be a child. Where is the "double thumps up" -Button? Such games deserve one!

content:
Posted: March 8, 2014
												This is my review on this beloved horror game, Amnesia The Dark Descent. This game is incredible and has amazing atmosphere and creepy jump scares, well, for the custom stories that is. The story goes like this. Your name is Daniel and you enter a creepy castle and have to try and kill someone named Alexander of Brennenberg and this game is all about the stealth! Yes, STEALTH! You can't kill any enemies you just have to simply hide and wait, or just run away from them or, you can troll them and try to kill them which I don't know what's the fun in that but that's my opinion. Anyways this game is just so much fun and Frictional Games also made a DLC called Justine which is pretty difficult, if you die you have to start all over again and you also get to choose if you wanna save the prisoner's or kill them, which I always like to be evil. Also I highly suggest you play the game with your headphones and full blast and in a dark room cause that just makes it even more possible for you to get very scared. Frictional Games made another series before this called Penumbra which is very good I've seen Markiplier play it and I wanna play it myself but it won't let me (which makes me VERY sad), and there's 3 games, there's Overture, Black Plague and Requim which is just kinda like a DLC which a LOT ofth very hard puzzles (from what I've heard). Frictional has also FINALLY made the sequel to Amnesia called A Machine For Pigs which, I will make a review on that, not going to say anything on that subject *shudders* but yea that's pretty much all I can think of. This is my first review and I'm terrible at doing them I hope you can bare with me on that. So if you haven't played the game I hope this will tempt you to go and buy it and get scared as hell cause, a lot of the custom stories are VERY scary (coming from a guy who doesn't get scared at all)! Well there ya have it, that's all I've got on my noggin so I'll see ya guys next time for my next review and, have a great day all and one last thing to say, you'd better have a lot of pants! PEACE OUT!

content:
Posted: April 30, 2013
												WARNING: This recommendation contains mild spoilers. I'll keep them to a minimum though.I first heard about Amnesia: The Dark Descent when some of my friends were talking about it. They didn't tell much but it seemed interesting enough to have a look at it. I always had some really creepy games in my "Best games I've ever played"-list, but I had not played anything like Amnesia before.So what is it about? Your name is Daniel and you're from London, Mayfair. That's all you know when you wake up from being unconscious. You are in a medieval-looking castle and have no idea how you got there. Nobody is around so you wander around the castle looking for answers. Eventually you find a note that is addressed to you and was written by - yourself. The information in this note is the only clue you have while wandering the castle of Brennenburg, in a desperate search for answers while trying to get away from whatever is trying to hunt you down.Unlike many other titles that are labeled horror, Amnesia: The Dark Descent is not a hybrid type game like a horror shooter or a horror-RPG. You cannot simply blast your way through the castle using fancy weapons or magic. Daniel hasn't got any kind of weapon and - surprise - he will never find one. Still there are enemies within the castle, and they are not the ones to be reasoned with. Your only means of self-defense are running and hiding. In most situations the latter one is preferable. Dark places are great if you don't want to be seen but hiding in the dark also exposes Daniel to the horrors within his own mind. You find yourself constantly wondering if you should light the candles in a room to avoid going crazy while being at risk of being found.Amnesia: The Dark Descent is all about immersion. There is no HUD and your two most important resources - health and sanity - aren't represented by definite numbers. You have to keep both in mind, though. The game physics highly contributes to the immersive experience. If you want to open a drawer you don't simply click it. Instead you grab it using your mouse and draw it towards you. That also makes it possible to either open doors slowly and with great care or to slam them shut.Amnesia not your generic horror-ish game, it's the real deal. It is not about fighting your way through hordes of enemies or being the hero who saves the world. The whole game is about nothing but atmosphere. If you can appreciate that Amnesia: The Dark Descent is a definitive must-buy.More reviews here

Posted: November 15, 2016
												Amnesia is a well known game, and there's not much to tell so I am directing this to SOMA fans who are curious about trying it out. Do it. It's not a technical masterpiece, but you won't care soon, since the atmosphere is so suffocating and drenched in dread and decay. And some things you do in there just to survive are just... deplorable, mental. Frictional Games knows horror, knows that the monster is not the one chasing you, but the environment and atmosphere itself, the story, idea, and possibly you. It stayed with me for a few days now.So, SOMA fans, jump in.

number of helpful: 6 of 6 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 28, 2016
												A great Lovecraftian tale that gradually unfolds with increasing dread. Your only defense against fear, insanity, and death is light, which I was able to find quite abundantly in the form of tinderboxes which are used to spark the fairly frequently encountered candelabras.  Perhaps higher difficulties reduce that frequency. Regardless, there were more than a few nailbiting moments to make this an enjoyable and frightening descent to the end (which comes all too quickly).  It is a parts-gathering and puzzle-solving type game, ala Myst, but the puzzles are fairly simple and don't detract from the story.  If you're looking for a challenging game to eat up countless hours, this isn't that. But if you're looking for an eldritch tale of otherworldly horrors, greed, murder, and madness, this is worth picking up.

number of helpful: 6 of 6 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 24, 2016
												This is my absolute favourite game off all time. Immersion is what this game does best, which is the result of all parts of this game going well together. Examples of these parts are the minimal interface (even the crosshair can be turned off), the ability to interact with almost everything, the fact that the game doesn't lagg even on very bad computers and the perfectly timed and well-suited soundtracks and ambience sounds. I consider Frictional Games a company that uses games as a way to tell a story. The storyline of this game fascinates me, there's little I don't know about it and I'm always up for discussion. The game might only be about 4 to 7 hours long, but I've played it at least 7 times. Combined with the hundreds of fan-made 'custom stories' that I've played, I must be at over 300 hours played right now. If you need any more information, type the name of this game on Youtube and my video will probably pop up as one of the first. I did a full non-commentary playthrough back in 2012, and am always responding to the comments.

content:
Posted: February 10
Product received for free
												This is one of the scariest games in recent memory. The loading screen recommends you turn the lights off and play with headphones, something I'll strongly echo. Amnesia: The Dark Descent's puzzles aren't especially impressive and the voice acting can range from convincing to goofy, but the atmosphere Frictional has infused into the experience is as powerful as they come. It's a tale of terror that's menacing and disturbing from the very first moments, and only amplifies the further you progress. Any fan of horror, every Lovecraft fan, and any with even a hint of curiosity should give Amnesia a shot. Few games are able to conjure up an atmosphere this genuinely frightening.

content:
Posted: October 6, 2014
												Amnesia is an awesome horror game that replaces jumpscares with a creepy, immersive atmosphere. The game includes a lot of puzzles which aren't insanely complex but still require a decent amount of intelligence to complete. Personally I think the story is great, lots of information is scattered around the halls of Brennenburg in the form of notes. These notes are often accompanied by the great dialogue that makes an appearance in the game every so often. The voice acting is brilliant but unfortunately it's not featured as much as I would like it to be, simply because there is a small amount of characters. And of course the monsters... the monsters play a huge role in the game. As if the terrifying atmosphere wasn't enough you will also be filled with paranoia knowing that there could be a monster waiting behind every door you open, every corner you peek around. Arguably the best thing about the game is "Custom stories", there are thousands of levels to download online that are made by the community so that you can keep playing even after you have completed the main story! If you want a horror game that will keep you constantly frightened, but also curious to discover what will happen next then you should definitely try out Amnesia.OverviewPros- Absolutely terrifying atmosphere (better than cliché jumpscares, imo)- Great story- Awesome voice acting- Community made levels, often have amazing stories.Cons- Puzzles sometimes become tedious- No combat (This boils down to preference)

number of helpful: 7 of 8 people (88%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2013
												I'll start by putting the pieces in one by one on how GREAT this game is.     First off is the story. You know, a lot of game developers don't make "amnesia" a good cliche. On fact, when game devs have amnesia, it usually has that character never remember anything at all in the end of a game and leaves gamers with more questions than answers. Other games have characters remember things until the very end of the game (not going to name games in case of spoilers). But this game starts with a man named Daniel, who wakes up with no memory inside of a castle. He finds a note to the Daniel that remembers. Daniel starts to constantly find notes to himself and starts to remember who he really is. While he is trying to find out who he is, Daniel is on a quest to do what the first note said. To kill a man named Alexander. As Daniel treks through the humongous castle, his sanity starts to fall down and he starts finding strange phenomena like a monster stalking his every move. Daniel must kill Alexander... before his sanity kills himself. This dark story will have you scared to go in the dark, and what the darkness might hold for you.     Next up, the gameplay. The gameplay takes the same of a survival horror genre. You need a lanter to light up your way AND to not lose your sanity, for sanity is the key to how much monster encounters you will get. While being "hunted", you are forced to decide wether to run or hide. Hiding is a great option when there are props everywhere to hide yourself in. If you have no place to hide, well♥♥♥♥♥♥ You can try to crouch your way around the monster, or you can YOLO and sprint but have to remember that he can hear footsteps. When you are at these spots where the monster can be around every corner, you will be in corridors, light or dark, with very dark, distorted, music. Leaving what horror is supposed to be about. The suspense. The suspense this game gives you is nerve-wracking. I was in so much suspense playing this game, I was scared ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ when someone made a Skype call. What part I love about the gameplay is that they will have rooms that are for puzzles and gaining your sanity back so you can go back in and get scared again. Kind of reminds me of Silent Hill: Shattered Memories.     Next, the graphics. Who gives a♥♥♥♥♥♥about the graphics?     The last part will be the custom stories. SOME people can make GREAT custom stories. I have played a lot of custom stories and all of them are unique in their own way, either making it for a great story, made to scare people, or just to have some fun with you and your friends. Some custom stories were even more scary than the original story. Want to play Amnesia but don't want to play the real story? No problem just slap a custom story in your files and play away! For those who want to play a custom but do not know how to install them, this video should help you. 


YouTube™ Video: Cry Explains: How the Hell to Install Custom Stories [Amnesia] [Steam] 

			Views: 124,109		

			Because for some reason, people don't know how to do this. I don't know why, but, well, okay. FINE. http://www.moddb.com http://www.rarlab.com And yes. I know my wallpaper is amazing.		

     Amnesia: The Dark Descent is a great game for so many reasons. This game is a great game to buy when on sale and it is on sale a lot. Close this review, get on the store and buy a copy of Amnesia right away........ I'm waiting.

content:
Posted: October 18, 2016
Product received for free
												Immersion is often a difficult task to achieve in the world of video games, and it is here where "Amnesia: The Dark Descent" is the prime example of how to do it right. Especially where a mechaic like "sanity" is so rarely used in the horror genre, "Amnesia" is unlike any other: it is brutal, creative, and has some of the best sound quality I've ever heard in a game. The puzzles are fun, and the monsters terrifying; even when the scares might become repeative, they are enough to draw your breath away everytime. When it comes to horror, "Amnesia: The Dark Descent" is simply one of the best, and is a must-play for any wanting a story to get you thinking, and an atmosphere to give you nightmares.

content:
Posted: April 29, 2016
												With everything you've already heard about Amnesia, know this - you can only take its hype so far. Yes, it's a delightfully scary game with a real sense of accomplishment after every puzzle you complete and monster you run from. But it's not so scary that you should immediately dismiss it if it's "not your genre" or you're "too scared". Any adult gamer owes it to themselves to pick up this game up if only for how well it is able to create a believable atmosphere with simplistic visuals, conveying information through text (an obvious limitation), and one of the best-sounding indie games of its time. AAA titles and indie games that want to venture into horror game making can take something out of this from a sound design standpoint. Visually, it's delicious. The textures and effects work to display an ominous ancient castle in the 1880s with a steampunk aesthetic for its puzzle elements. The use of props, mechanics, and an inventory system works. It doesn't fare against today's AAAs, but it's going to look damn good on whatever you're playing it on. If you also play it on the correct brightness level (you'd only be cheating yourself), it adds another level of immersion. The puzzle mechanics are great, but can get needlessly redundant and complex if you don't read some of the lore. If the papers are in the Notes section, they're worth reading. Sprinting mechanics and how the controls work when you're going insane felt strangely natural. Monsters spooked. The pick up, throw, and move object controls were also relieving - sometimes you just wanted to hurl a chair, a skull, or a body of other props in the air for no good reason other than to see it fly away. The only way you could tell this was a budgeted game was through its use of limited narration in its story texts. Most information is conveyed through what's written down on pieces of paper, and a limited voiceover from a few characters on a few documents (not all are voiced over) made me lose interest. But there were times in the journey where the your world would slow so that the protagonist could remember moments that were mostly delivered only through dialogue and sound. Those moments more than balanced out the chunks of text that were both spoken and unspoken. With its limited scope and mechanics for it being a budgeted title, the length felt right. It has 3 types of endings, which fit within its lofty lore that surrounds it. The checkpoint system was forgiving, and I wouldn't have had that any other way. Another gripe was that once you died or initially encountered the same few monsters, it felt less spooker than I anticipated. But the scores and sound cues that accompanied their presence hooked me back into it. TL:DR++ P H E N O M E N A L  sound design in every step in the process, whether you're using on board audio or a top-notch sound card. + Short, but sweet game w/ interesting puzzles+ Fresh spin on old environments with great visuals+ Simple mechanics in a complex world+/- Most information delivered through text, can feel a bit like a visual novel at points- Characters not as memorable as the setting, which I found to be a missed opportunity- Monster interactions got tedious and boring at points8.5/10 - A great game for anyone coming from any genre background. This game also has a semi-active modding community on modDB that can provide tens of hours of new stories and campaign that reaches from Amnesia's rich backstory. One of my best Humble Bundle fringe purchases to this date.

content:
Posted: January 27
												One of the scariest games of all time. As someone who values a good survival horror game, Amnesia: The Dark Descent is one of the greatest. The game has no combat function and forces you to flee from your enemies within a dark castle located somewhere in the woods of Prussia. You play as Daniel, a man who has no memory of who he is, but who has left a note to himself describing the terrifying shadow which follows you along with your main mission, which is to kill a man named Alexander.The game play mechanics are fantastic. If you are in a dark area for too long, you will start to lose your sanity and hallucinate. You are able to remedy this by using tinder boxes to light candles and torches along the way. If, however, you look directly at the monster who constantly pursues you, you lose a great deal of sanity almost immediately. The lack of combat leaves you feeling vulnerable and scared as you turn each corner of the castle, dreading what may be around the turn. Instead of fighting, you are forced to run and hide from your assailant, which I found refreshing, although there have been many titles to repeat this after this game was released. Overall, this game is great. If you are a fan of horror games, you won't want to miss this one.

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 28, 2016
Product received for free
												I was gifted this game off of a friend after viewing some playthroughs and expressing my interest in trying to play the game myself, and needless to say, I didn't find myself disappointed. Just as I believe the creators of Amnesia wanted, the game was atmospheric and compelling from start to finish. What I have in high regard about this game is the use of wit to survive rather than fighting skills, alongside it's several small puzzles and memory trips that added to the game. As for the actual gameplay itself, the entirety of the game ran smoothly and was more than easy to get to grips with, although I was stupid and didn't actually realise you could sprint until over halfway through the game (its Shift + W by the way.) On the contrary, the only thing I'd personally alter about this game is the detail of the storyline and lack of  interaction. I'm aware that the isolation of the games main character is what adds to the atmosphere, but some kind of interaction would've made the storyline a lot more interesting for me, rather than a dozen flashbacks and lengthy notes/diaries. As a person who enjoys progression in a game a lot more than having to read long-winded notes and excerpts, I feel as though this would've been what could of made the game for me, but that's a matter of opinion. Either way, the storyline is easy enough to understand without reading a single note anyways, which is a good plus to the game. I found that generally, Amnesia's story was somewhat fascinating and original, but the normal ending that I had experienced was a little disappointing after 11 hours of gameplay and not as intense as I'd of expected. Whilst a few things let me down within the game, these are all minor/opinions, and there is nothing legitimate at fault. I'd recommend this game as a must-play for any horror fan to try out at least once.

content:
Posted: July 12, 2016
												Not only is this one of the best horror games out there, it is also one of my favourite steam games. Even after completing the main story multiple times, I still have the urge to complete it again. Despite knowing the levels like the back of my hand, it still provides me with a nervous and always unsettling feeling while playing. The lore is also very interesting. Not to mention that custom stories are in plentiful supply. The reason why it exceeds so well is simply because of the gameplay and well implemented immersion. Whenever someone says "Dead Space is so scary OMG", I want to kill myself. Amnesia is so amazing and terrifying because you are defenseless, unlike Dead Space. You cannot fight back against the enemies in this game, which is why you're heart is always racing. It's such a simple concept yet it's so effective. This game will be remembered for a long time. Even if you aren't a horror person, you should definitely give this a try. It's a fantastic gaming experience.P.S. Play with headphones!

content:
Posted: September 20, 2016
												Its really a crying shame there aren't any movies being made these days that give me a deep sense of fear and trepidation like Amnesia The Dark Descent and so am eternally grateful to the game developers who continue to push the boundries of the horror genre.A great many games have been released since this game was iniatially launched and yet few stack up to its standard, as old as the game is its graphics don't fail to impress not a moment went by that I didn't take a moment whilst hiding in a dark corner or♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥myself in a wardrobe to take in the ambience of the dark, twisted environments my poor character had the gross misfortune to find himself in.The pure malevonance of the castle I was trapped in was only further imbued by terror due in no small part to the downright twisted ambient music flowing through my Turtle Beaches and into my head causing me to proceed more cautiously and with a sense of pure anxiety that had me sweating so much it felt as though I would slip right off my chair at any moment.With a non-invasive UI that didn't take away from the gameplay and an easy to use inventory system the only problem I found was rationing my supplies as to not get caught in the dark without a light source or a rapidly diminishing mental state, which would leave my character crippled with fear or worse.For those who like fast gameplay and linear storylines, this game is not for you if however you love a solid story that plumbs the very depths of human darkness and surviving my the skin of your teeth, not to mention quaking in terror at an effective horror title then step on in and enjoy the ride, I promise you, you won't be disappointed.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 25, 2016
												So it has been 6 years since this game release and does it holds up? Well to be honest with you I don't play a lot of horror games because it is not my cup of tea. I play it mostly to amuse myself but after playing this game it really holds up good. The game shines by its uneasy atmosphere and the developers really did a great job doing that. I feel everytime when I get into some unsettling creepy section room I say "I want to get out man, where's the exit." I don't usually get really scare but man some part of the game just gives me an intense feeling whenever something bad is about to happen, spook me a few times just by hearing random noise.STORYI will say this that story isn't the strongest suit especially from the beginning. You will get lost of what the hell is the main character talking about his notes and additional dialogue that you either care or don't and just want to move on your destination. Though in the middle or even at the end you'll start to atleast understand what this whole story is about once you collect enough notes of the diary and when you really want to get invested of the story than you can read it whole in Daniel's dairy. I sort of got bored midway through Daniel's rambling till almost the end I finally took notice of the lore and I took an interest of it so is not the most boring if you can persevere the plot. Now one thing I find it amusing of the plot is Daniel's persisted to kill Alexander even if it means to going through danky sewers, subjecting to smell rotten food and corpses, while running away those grunts (which I called them Big Lip "Monster moment" since they appear for a moment and dissapear on the next,) and all kinds of monsters out there. I got to give him credit though for being that brave, I would just high tail out of here telling the constable the whole story and never set foot on that castle again!ENEMIES I will tell you now there are practically little enemies in this game but the biggest enemy you have to watch out for; is your sanity, with no weapons to defend and you know what it works perfectly! Yeah I wish there are atleast two more enemies because I got a little tired of looking that big lip grunts all the time and once you hear that screech you know is avoid, hide, don't hear the music building up, move on and repeat. Thankfuly once again the atmosphere and your sanity meter helps you build up fear to those three monsters in hair standing moments. Because the only monster I didn't find it scary is the invisible water monster, that creature had potential but ultimately you just don't touch the water and you're good to go. The brute I only see once in my first playthrough and I only look at him for a second! Base of what I heard about him, he's a tougher version of the grunt that is all. I understand the game's purpose of no weapon and you must hide from the monsters, but sometimes I find it funny through Daniel's observation that why couldn't he atleast use some of the tools that looks assualt enough to attack them, or atleast throw it. (I thought when I grab the crow bar I would be like Gordon Freeman, turns out I was wrong and decide to throw at the grunt...big mistake.) I guess Daniel son hasn't learn self-defence yet.HEALTH/SANITYThe 2nd key point of the game is keeping your sanity in check because if you don't you will start hallucinate and your vision will become drunk as demoman himself! Though honesty I find the sanity meter a bit dissapointment than it is "ooooh gotch I better keep that in check" Because drunken vision and seeing cockeroach with blood on walls doesn't help me become scare it just makes me have to wait till my brain is less insane and then I move on to the next. Eternal Darkness from the gamecube did it better in terms of sanity effect because it just breaks the 4th wall of the game and it was awesome! Light apparently is essential for keeping that meter check so always carry tinder and oil. You won't believe how chill moments when you find out you only have little oil and only one can left, ss a good feel of conservative! But sadly that sort of taking away the meaning of light when your sanity anyway will drop fast just by a sudden event you did or that shaky earthquake that my meter goes down fast. I don't know if I'm thinking wrong but to me it happens to me always especially even if my head is clear, a grunt appear and is bad to having that pounding headache.Don't get me started with the health meter, the health meter is practically useless. Why? Because almost nothing can kill you except the enemies. Those red blog things that hurt you, it won't kill you, falling from ledges, nope trust me I tried many times to test it unless you hurt yourself repeatedly. When it said I'm bleeding badly it heals back to bruise and cuts so having that laudanum is pretty much the lease worry of your problem of your journey unless that effects your sanity meter in which case I apologies. If you get killed don't worry it will reset to the closest section you died and you'll still have your items with you.SUMMARYGreat horror game, great atmosphere and good puzzles too, though I wish they hinted the puzzles just a little more for some of the confusing puzzles but that's just a nitpick. Another good thing about this game is mod support so you will get additional fan custom stories which makes it repeatable playthroughs with different fan stories. I give it an 8/10 for still holding up to its age.

content:
Posted: September 15, 2013
												Whenever someone asks me what Amnesia: the Dark Descent is, I tell them it is the scariest game they will ever play. I stand by that assessment. I tried to play through it two years ago; I got an hour into the game, saw one of the monsters, and hid in a closet (in the game) until it went away. I decided to take a break and come back to the game a little later. Two years later I finally came back to the game and I have finished it!Amnesia is scary not through jump scares and carefully scripted events, but through the oppressive and tense atmosphere that is constantly pressing in on you. This is the kind of scary that really affects me, because I tend to psyche myself up more than any scripted events will. It also means that you will only be scared if you let yourself become immersed in the environment; this is why I played in a dark room, alone, with headphones on whenever possible.You play as Daniel, who wakes up in an old Prussian castle with no memories of who he is. You soon find a note to yourself that kind of explains the situation. Apparently there is a bad man named Alexander in the bowels of the castle, and you have to go down there and kill him. There is also a Shadow hunting you, breaking down reality; you cannot fight it, your only choice is to run and hide.Lighting plays a critical role in this game. Not only does it determine how far you can see, but if you spend too much time in the darkness Daniel will start to lose his sanity, and then you can't trust the things he sees. To combat this you can light candles in the environment with tinderboxes and you can use your lantern. You have to be careful not to use too many tinderboxes or oil though, which adds another layer of tension.You can get sanity back by solving puzzles and progressing through the game. Most of the puzzles force you to explore and find items in areas that you would probably rather avoid.It took me seven and a half hours to complete the game. I am glad that it wasn't longer, because by the end I was starting to recognize the mechanics underlying the puzzles and monsters, and I was having trouble immersing myself as much as I had in the beginning.Obviously if you don't enjoy scary movies you won't want to pick this game up, but if you do I highly recommend Amnesia: the Dark Descent. It is well worth the $20 price tag.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 28, 2015
												A study in fear!Great "lovecraft-ish" gothic atmosphere and an inability to fight back the game's monsters are what make Amnesia so unique in the survival horror genre, despite the heavy antagonism it has.In itself, Amnesia offers a great horror story, in which the player is put in the very shoes of the game's protagonist, who, as the title suggests, suffers from amnesia and, much like the player, has no idea where he is and what he is doing, all set in a huge and magnificent gothic castle.Adding to the atmosphere we have the game's awesome soundtrack, with its silent to very tense sounds, up to the Terror Meter track (seriously, click 'n' listen to it!), which represents the epitome of Amnesia's scary soundtrack, as it is the game's own way of telling you that a monster has seen and is chasing you!Speaking of the game's enemies, the variety is quite small: 3 types of monsters (a basic one, a stronger one and an invisible water one) and a final (easy) boss fight, but believe me when I say they are more than enough when you are running for your life, with your heart beating like crazy, desperate to find a place to hide!And that brings me to the game's most distinctive feature: the lack of any weapon whatsoever and thus of any effective way to kill the monsters, which is what truly makes the game this scary (though, truth be said, there IS an indirect way to kill the monsters and that is to stand on a high top, close to a precipice and then lure the monster to catch you, leading it to its fall.. I managed it once, felt really good)!A testament of the game's scariness is in the fact that this is one of the very few games I played with a walkthrough open for almost the total duration of it, in order to anticipate the monsters' attacks (never did it before on games like Doom 3, Dead Space etc., where you could always blast any monster away with your super guns), such is the feeling of fear Amnesia emanates (the Prison level has to be one of the most scary and dark levels ever!).Assisting this scary feature is also the game's darkness, a darkness unlike any other you have ever seen (tops even the one in Doom 3, though only by a little, since the protagonist's eyes adjust to the darkness when you are left with no light at all, much like it would happen in real life, quite an awesome feature) and which makes you really value the oil lamp and tinderboxes you are provided!Even your sanity is measured in the game, aside from your health, which increases the more you meet monsters and stay in the darkness!As the game progresses and the pile of bricks amasses, you learn more and more about the castle's story and what happened to the protagonist in the way a true H.P. Lovecraft tribute should be, while (some of) your choices affect the game and can bring you up to 4 different endings!As a final note, don't miss the game's free DLC, Amnesia: Justine, which features a 19th century "Saw"-like story. Seriously, it has everything to remind you of that: an abducted character that wakes up in a cell with no idea of when and what, a recorded phonograph with instructions from the abductor for his "game", the choice to save other abducted prisoners and alter your ending and a final great twist. Of course the horrid monsters that can chase and kill you on the spot are present, with still no (direct) means to kill them and, to make things more tense, there is also no way to save your progress in this DLC, but it's lifespan is short anyways.To complete your experience, read the Amnesia: Remember short stories as well, also given for free with the game in a pdf file.I'll be sure to play the game's sequel someday, Amnesia: A Machine for Pigs, though I'll let quite some time pass first, to have the experience sink a bit more.Final verdict: totally recommended for survival horror fans, especially those that want to try something different in the genre!

content:
Posted: January 9, 2015
Quick SummaryA very recognizable horror title that doesn't rely on predictable jump scares.Purchase Verdict:  YesPoints of Interest-There's actually an interesting story at work in this game, and multiple endings can be achieved. However, it is mainly up to the player to collect journal entries and notes if they want to understand the entire story.-Creates an awesome atmosphere of paranoia and fear without relying on gimmicky jump scares.-Extremely interactive enviroment. Lots of things can be picked up, moved, thrown, pushed, etc. This adds to the immersion.-Requires player to manage their items, (i.e. oil and flint), but not to the point where it distracts from the atmosphere.-Puzzles are simple for the most part.

content:
Posted: April 17, 2016
												Well, what can I say about Amnesia? Scary? YesMakes you jump out of your seat? YesBecome afraid of water? YesThese are just some of what happened in the game. Basically, in case you've never seen/heard of it, its an atmospheric horror game, set in the days before electricity, and you're in the dark, gloomy places you wish never existed. You have a lantern, and a limited amount of tinder that you can find. And you're trying to survive everything that is thrown at you.Some parts are quiet, and then you hear a roar, and as its in the dark and you've run out of oil, you stumble to try and find a corner to hide in, and prey it doesn't see you.Overall, its a great game. I actually played this in the dark, no lights etc. My keyboard is black, and there are no lights on it, so I immersed myself into the game.Playing with headphones on (as I was recording for Let's Play), when you're out of a light source for too long, your sanity starts to go, and you hear scratching noises. Headphones on, feels like its at the back of your own skull.Recommend to anyone that like a scare, some puzzles are annoying but the overall game is fantastic!!10/10And here's a little review I did of the game :)

content:
Posted: March 16, 2014
												Okay. Where to begin? First of all, this game is scary. VERY scary. But not the sort of scary that you see in modern horror like when you turn around and the monster's appeared right behind you and a loud noise plays sort of scary. It relies more on stealth, and the fear comes from the anticipation of being found by the monster(s). Also, add in that if you hide in the darkness too long you start going mad and hallucinating all sorts of awful things, it becomes just that much more tense. Second of all, the story is AMAZING. It's not like the sort of story where you walk down straight corridors and it's explained to you in cutscenes. Oh no. You have to look around the castle for notes that explain the story, but not in order. You will find one note that explains the nature of your friendship with Alexander in Castle Brenenburg, then you will find a note some levels afterward that explains why you went to castle Brenenburg in the first place. Oh, and if you avoid hunting down the notes, you will be very confused towards the end. And as incentive to hunt down these notes, they restore the player's sanity (if I remember correctly). Thirdly, the graphics. While they may not be the highest resolution or highest poly, the castle and everything in it looks damn good. The best part of all was the lighting. The devs clearly knew how different forms of lighting affects the human mind, making a simple shower room look like a gateway into hell. That is, until you bring up your lantern or use a tinderbox. All in all, this is probably the best horror game. Ever. Better than F.E.A.R., or Slender: The Eight Pages, or any of those countless horror flash games on the web. While in those games, you simply walk from point A to B and watch jumpscares happen in cutscenes, in Amnesia, you will feel like you are Daniel, and you will understand his motivations and his many flaws, and you will feel in peril during the entire game. 10/10

content:
Posted: March 6, 2011
												Many games attempting the horror genre miss the point of horror entirely by giving you too many weapons, throwing several enemies at you and lacking pacing with a spooky atmosphere.  Well my friends, Amnesia is here and your bowels are about to betray you. The game sets you in a horrifying, dark world, eliminating the comforting heft of any weapons and pitting you against deadly enemies you must sneak around and hide from to survive, all the while solving puzzles and keeping your sanity in check to progress.  The game is a short one, well around 5 - 6 hours, but it took me a week to beat based entirely on the fact that I kept fearquitting, or bringing up the Steam web browser to watch stupid crap on YouTube to get my nerves back.  The story and three alternate endings have a chance to confuse a bit and it may take some paying hard attention to fully understand the story, but it's a good one nonetheless.  Fans of the horror genre, your search is finally over.

content:
Posted: January 28, 2015
												Amnesia: The Dark Descent is kind of a survival horror, where you actually can't do anything about monsters. Hiding is a good strategy. Darkness is your best friend, but also your biggest threat. Alright, these were a few out-of-review sentences, now something about the game itself:Amnesia doesn't have a really epic graphic, but it really makes out for the atmosphere, wchich is by far purely amazing. The well-made audio cover also adds to the horror-style. Game uses the mechanic of "Sanity meter" - if you lose it all, you'll fall on the ground and will be unable to move for a few seconds. Standing in darkness for too long or looking at monsters will make your sanity drop pretty fast. There's also a health meter. Your main light source will be a lantern and tinderboxes.Our horror runs perfectly without any problems, but I encountered a few glitches (falling through the floor, missing models), although these aren't really annoying and won't happen too often. The monsters' AI is good, but not perfect. They sometimes bug on doors / walls or ignore all sounds. The storyline can be a little bit confusing, but if you collect all the puzzles and match them, then you'll understand it.There is also an option to play custom stories (fan-made bonus stories, you can download them on Mod DB, for example), which really extends the fun of playing.Now everything what I said in short words.Pros:-Amazing atmosphere-Scary monsters-Good storyline-Well-made audio cover-Neverending fun (Including main story and fan-made custom stories)Cons:-Bugs 'n' glitches-Can be too confusing in a few times-Not everyone may like this concept of gamePersonal rating: A great classical horror, which should be in every horror lover's library.Traditional rating: 9/10, greatly recommended

content:
Posted: March 3
												It might be a strange thing to say after 12 hours on record, but I don't really like graphic horror. It grosses me out. Which makes it all the more amazing that Amnesia: The Dark Descent grew on me the longer I played, mostly because there's so much about this game they actually did right.. It's an atmospheric survival adventure that tells a complex narrative as you stumble around a very dark place, literally and figuratively. So much could have gone wrong about this formula, but didn't.The pacing feels just right. They ease you in, feeding you just enough mysteries to keep you interested before you get to the fast-paced survival and cerebral puzzle parts. Puzzles aren't of the impossibly hard variety, which is because they're nicely logical. Everything about your enivronment works and reacts very intuitively, it all feels natural, which means this game actually rewards observation and logical thinking in every step you take. The narrative is told by flashbacks and written notes you uncover along your way, which isn't nearly as wooden and obstrusive as it sounds. The dose feels just right. It's also one of the few games where bad visibility actually provides creepy mood rather than plain annoyance.I would have appreciated a bit less of the gory and disturbing stuff, as the creepy atmosphere alone really stands its ground. But add good writing, good pacing and convenient mechanics, and what you have here is a rather competently executed game. If you have even a passing interest in adventure or survival games and don't mind the gross stuff, you probably want this.

												It's one of the scariest games I've ever had the (dis)pleasure of playing.  I'm normally not one for the horror genre, but this flavor of it is something that sinks in deep with me.  That psychological despair which lingers with you throughout the entire story, and the dread of being hunted.  Honestly, it doesn't get any better than that, and Frictional Games knows it.  Admittedly, the scare tactic in this game gets a bit predictable after a while, and the levels aren't anything spectacular.  Where this game really hits home is the ambience; it alone will fill you with unease.  If you haven't played this game yet, you're missing out.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 25, 2014
												Amnesia is a game that has become infamous since its release as one of the most terrifying horror games of the past decade or so. How true that claim might be is difficult to say as fear and horror is a rather subjective issue, but to give my own experiences... I've played a lot of horror games in my time, and Amnesia is definitely one of my top favorites, as well as one of the few to genuinely disturb me while playing.You play as Daniel, a British artifact curator who has come into the company of a Prussian baron, Alexander of Brannenburg, in the early 19th century. For reasons initially unknown to you at current, Daniel and Alexander have had a falling out, resulting in Daniel consuming an amnesia-inducing potion and leaving a letter to himself telling him to seek out Alexander in the depths of his castle and kill him. As Daniel progresses through the castle, he experiences flashbacks and memory relapses which combined with journal notes and cryptic loading screen texts tell Amnesia's story. The entire thing is very DIY and requires the player to be attentive, as only the basics of the plot are handed out easily to the player. However, the end result is well worth the effort, as the bigger picture coming together creates a realization that only adds to the horror of the game.What makes Amnesia's horror stand out, however, is the dynamic which light and darkness have an effect on Daniel as you creep through Brannenburg castle. The longer you stay in the darkness (and this game gets PITCH BLACK DARK), the more your sanity drops. As your sanity drops, your controls become loose, vision becomes warped and distorted, and Daniel may hallucinate things that are not there, causing delays. When his sanity gets too low, he essentially buckles over onto the floor and collapses in a paranoid heap for a long while, leaving you vulnerable. The remedy to this is to stay in lit areas, which slowly restores sanity. However, staying in the light is dangerous as it makes you visible to any monsters that are creeping nearby and they will make short work of you if seen. This contradictory dynamic makes the entire game a stress inducing nightmare where you must constatly think about when it is safe to stay in the light and when you need to hide and lose sanity, as well as managing your limited supply of tinderboxes to lighten up candles which can either provide you with a safe haven or deny you a place to hide should you come across an enemy. You are never truly safe, but you always have some control over your situtation, and this dynamic is what makes Amnesia stand out from other horror games, especially "helpess" ones where you can not fight back.There are other elements which add to the experience of the game, namely atmosphere, sound design, and disturbing imagery, and all of them are utilized fairly responsibly to deliver an unnerving experience. The game is largely built around simple to modest adventure game style puzzles, which a fair amount of exploration and searching involved to find what you need. It isn't the most inventive or intuitive problem solving, but it gets the job done and does not distract from the core attraction of the game which is the fear and horror. The story is top notch in my opinion and the characters of both Daniel and Alexander are well fleshed out and written, and as said before piecing together the story whole adds a whole new layer to the fear in the game. The main destriment is honestly the consequences of death, or real lack thereof. Getting killed does little to punish you for your mistakes, except the loss of items you may have used in a vain attempt to survive beforehand. Otherwise the game treats death as a light slap on the wrist and resets you at the most recent save point, which is often the door you just came in through. That said, the actual fear of one of the monsters coming at you and slicing you up can make up for it, perhaps. Lastly, Amnesia supports custom modules for unique, player-made games and there are plenty of top-quality ones out there to try, so even after the game loses its luster there are fresh new terrors to experience, many of them providing their own unique twists and scares.If you're a fan of adventure games or horror games, Amnesia is definitely worth looking into. Looks past the hype and praise and instead let yourself become immersed in its story and atmosphere, and there is a good chance you won't be dissapointed. But don't play Justine. Justine is really bad.

content:
Posted: October 19, 2016
												Don't mind my hours, I've played most of my time on another account.But yeah, this is one of my favorite horror games of all time. This a game from the time when horror games required more than just a defenseless protagonist and some strobe lighting (machine for pigs I'm looking at you). +Looks great (espesially lighting)+Is actually scary without having many jumpscares+The physics engine is fantastic+Sounds are the best of the best and same goes for the music+Difficulty: it's far from a walking simulator (amfp :P) but the monsters are actually very easy to avoid and they are there just to keep the game interesting+Sanity system and limited light resources±The story is ok, but it's told in paper notes so be ready to read alot. No cutscenes though...-...except the flashbacks, which are total pain in the♥♥♥♥♥when you replay the main story±Custom stories gave this game almost infinite amount of content (even though the quality of them is highly varied :P)-Has some tedious parts-The game loses a bit of its scariness every time you die-The AI doesn't exist: the monsters are programmed to patrol for short time somewhere for a couple of minutes before they vanish completely. If you are spotted, they will chase you for couple of seconds and lose their interest at the same second they don't see you anymore. If you get killed by one of them, the same monster will never respawn again.-Performance scales from very good to very bad. Most of the time I get solid 60fps, but in some large areas I get some very annoying drops. Mostly lag spikes fortunately, nothing gamebreakingIn conclusion this is a very solid horror game that has some truly freaky moments. The main story alone doesn't last for too many playthroughs, but fortunately there is still an active mod community. I'd recommend to download at least Study of insanity and Black forest castle. If you like this you should also try Penumbra series and AVOID amnesia a machine for pigs! Be sure to play in dark room with good headphones and low gamma settings :)

content:
Posted: January 28, 2015
												Amnesia: The Dark Descent is kind of a survival horror, where you actually can't do anything about monsters. Hiding is a good strategy. Darkness is your best friend, but also your biggest threat. Alright, these were a few out-of-review sentences, now something about the game itself:Amnesia doesn't have a really epic graphic, but it really makes out for the atmosphere, wchich is by far purely amazing. The well-made audio cover also adds to the horror-style. Game uses the mechanic of "Sanity meter" - if you lose it all, you'll fall on the ground and will be unable to move for a few seconds. Standing in darkness for too long or looking at monsters will make your sanity drop pretty fast. There's also a health meter. Your main light source will be a lantern and tinderboxes.Our horror runs perfectly without any problems, but I encountered a few glitches (falling through the floor, missing models), although these aren't really annoying and won't happen too often. The monsters' AI is good, but not perfect. They sometimes bug on doors / walls or ignore all sounds. The storyline can be a little bit confusing, but if you collect all the puzzles and match them, then you'll understand it.There is also an option to play custom stories (fan-made bonus stories, you can download them on Mod DB, for example), which really extends the fun of playing.Now everything what I said in short words.Pros:-Amazing atmosphere-Scary monsters-Good storyline-Well-made audio cover-Neverending fun (Including main story and fan-made custom stories)Cons:-Bugs 'n' glitches-Can be too confusing in a few times-Not everyone may like this concept of gamePersonal rating: A great classical horror, which should be in every horror lover's library.Traditional rating: 9/10, greatly recommended
