content:
Posted: March 3
												It might be a strange thing to say after 12 hours on record, but I don't really like graphic horror. It grosses me out. Which makes it all the more amazing that Amnesia: The Dark Descent grew on me the longer I played, mostly because there's so much about this game they actually did right.. It's an atmospheric survival adventure that tells a complex narrative as you stumble around a very dark place, literally and figuratively. So much could have gone wrong about this formula, but didn't.The pacing feels just right. They ease you in, feeding you just enough mysteries to keep you interested before you get to the fast-paced survival and cerebral puzzle parts. Puzzles aren't of the impossibly hard variety, which is because they're nicely logical. Everything about your enivronment works and reacts very intuitively, it all feels natural, which means this game actually rewards observation and logical thinking in every step you take. The narrative is told by flashbacks and written notes you uncover along your way, which isn't nearly as wooden and obstrusive as it sounds. The dose feels just right. It's also one of the few games where bad visibility actually provides creepy mood rather than plain annoyance.I would have appreciated a bit less of the gory and disturbing stuff, as the creepy atmosphere alone really stands its ground. But add good writing, good pacing and convenient mechanics, and what you have here is a rather competently executed game. If you have even a passing interest in adventure or survival games and don't mind the gross stuff, you probably want this.

content:
Posted: October 25, 2014
												Amnesia is a game that has become infamous since its release as one of the most terrifying horror games of the past decade or so. How true that claim might be is difficult to say as fear and horror is a rather subjective issue, but to give my own experiences... I've played a lot of horror games in my time, and Amnesia is definitely one of my top favorites, as well as one of the few to genuinely disturb me while playing.You play as Daniel, a British artifact curator who has come into the company of a Prussian baron, Alexander of Brannenburg, in the early 19th century. For reasons initially unknown to you at current, Daniel and Alexander have had a falling out, resulting in Daniel consuming an amnesia-inducing potion and leaving a letter to himself telling him to seek out Alexander in the depths of his castle and kill him. As Daniel progresses through the castle, he experiences flashbacks and memory relapses which combined with journal notes and cryptic loading screen texts tell Amnesia's story. The entire thing is very DIY and requires the player to be attentive, as only the basics of the plot are handed out easily to the player. However, the end result is well worth the effort, as the bigger picture coming together creates a realization that only adds to the horror of the game.What makes Amnesia's horror stand out, however, is the dynamic which light and darkness have an effect on Daniel as you creep through Brannenburg castle. The longer you stay in the darkness (and this game gets PITCH BLACK DARK), the more your sanity drops. As your sanity drops, your controls become loose, vision becomes warped and distorted, and Daniel may hallucinate things that are not there, causing delays. When his sanity gets too low, he essentially buckles over onto the floor and collapses in a paranoid heap for a long while, leaving you vulnerable. The remedy to this is to stay in lit areas, which slowly restores sanity. However, staying in the light is dangerous as it makes you visible to any monsters that are creeping nearby and they will make short work of you if seen. This contradictory dynamic makes the entire game a stress inducing nightmare where you must constatly think about when it is safe to stay in the light and when you need to hide and lose sanity, as well as managing your limited supply of tinderboxes to lighten up candles which can either provide you with a safe haven or deny you a place to hide should you come across an enemy. You are never truly safe, but you always have some control over your situtation, and this dynamic is what makes Amnesia stand out from other horror games, especially "helpess" ones where you can not fight back.There are other elements which add to the experience of the game, namely atmosphere, sound design, and disturbing imagery, and all of them are utilized fairly responsibly to deliver an unnerving experience. The game is largely built around simple to modest adventure game style puzzles, which a fair amount of exploration and searching involved to find what you need. It isn't the most inventive or intuitive problem solving, but it gets the job done and does not distract from the core attraction of the game which is the fear and horror. The story is top notch in my opinion and the characters of both Daniel and Alexander are well fleshed out and written, and as said before piecing together the story whole adds a whole new layer to the fear in the game. The main destriment is honestly the consequences of death, or real lack thereof. Getting killed does little to punish you for your mistakes, except the loss of items you may have used in a vain attempt to survive beforehand. Otherwise the game treats death as a light slap on the wrist and resets you at the most recent save point, which is often the door you just came in through. That said, the actual fear of one of the monsters coming at you and slicing you up can make up for it, perhaps. Lastly, Amnesia supports custom modules for unique, player-made games and there are plenty of top-quality ones out there to try, so even after the game loses its luster there are fresh new terrors to experience, many of them providing their own unique twists and scares.If you're a fan of adventure games or horror games, Amnesia is definitely worth looking into. Looks past the hype and praise and instead let yourself become immersed in its story and atmosphere, and there is a good chance you won't be dissapointed. But don't play Justine. Justine is really bad.

content:
Posted: January 20, 2015
												And I have completed Amnesia: The Dark Descent and got all the endings as well.What do I think of this game? I'll give it an 9.Seriously this game got me on edge and there were times in the game where I refused to go even further into the game simply because I was frightened to go even further plus I didn't even know how to deal with this game when I first started as well. No weapons to defend yourself, your light is limited, you need to keep your sanity up so you wont get caught or worse lying on the ground trying to recover, You need to sneak and hide away from monsters that can two-one shot you to death?Scares?This game is good at setting up to make you go on edge and knowing what it's like to be defenseless to run and hide. It does make you afraid and Jumpscares is not just stereotypical either.. There is like a variety.. For example: Have a bunch of skulls hidden inside and when you open it pours out? Doesn't sound scary right? Wait til you hear the sound effects and your screen distort right before your eyes to make you feel uneasy. Though apparently if you set up some things right you get an interesting change of scare. For example if your Sanity is low enough then this picture and maybe some others distorts and changes accordingly to it.. Which is pretty damn clever.Does this game make worthy as a survival horror?I definitely would say yes to that since you have to muster your courage to proceed further into the game and find a way on how to deal with your fear and whatever can you do to survive and go further into the game. This game is dark and scary and there is a lot of puzzles that you need to do before you can even go further into the gameWhat didn't I like about the game?On various occasions you have your own enemies pulling a♥♥♥♥♥♥move on you and you have to run all the way back or somewhere where the enemy has lost sight of you and going back to patrol and it's usually the area where you need to get out in order to go further though that doesn't really count, This may be an issue to some other survival horror enthusiasts. Items are easy to miss and it is possible to think that you have overlooked something and that can be easy to do and I had to admit that I had to search a walkthrough to get unstuck at one particular part.Above all.Buy this game and don't let a Walk-through hold your hand throughout this horrifying experience. You came in for the story and the fear and wear headphones in a dark environment and turn off all the other monitors and focus only on the game. This game is brilliant to make you feel helpless and I sincerely recommend the thriller enthusiasts!

content:
Posted: September 21, 2015
												I played this game again, 5 years after its release and it hasn't aged at all. It is still a stand alone masterpiece in the horror genre. When people think of horror games, Amnesia has never ceased to come to mind. This title has remained number one for years and with hardly any competition.Those whom try to mimic Amnesia's success need to understand that this games most effective feature in inducing fear are not the monsters, but the atmosphere. The way in which sound and darkness are combined is simply brilliant. Without it, the monsters would seem like they do in any other B grade survival horror title.The game isn't all about running for your life, it has puzzle and exploration elements to keep you immersed in the eerie story.I am yet to see any game match Amnesia. Truly one of a kind.

content:
Posted: February 16, 2015
												Does this game really need an introduction? Amnesia: The Dark Descent is first person survival horror game with physics puzzles and stealth mechanics, but I'm sure you already knew that. This game is considered by many to be the apex of horror in gaming and is also known for being the main foot hold for many youtubers rise to fame. But that was just an unforeseen effect this game would have, Amnesia on its own merits is just pants wetting terrifying. The game starts off with you waking up in a dark and gothic castle and having no memory of anything but your name and where you're from (you have amnesia if the title didn't already make that clear). You must find a series of journal pages to uncover your own past and to understand what is going on in this castle. Through out the game you will encounter terrifying monsters that you have to avoid looking at due to a sanity meter, you need to maintain your sanity even though its separate from your health, it's just as important. This games atmosphere is well presented as you find yourself running and hiding from noises and even hallucinations. You will go to amazing locations and solve puzzles that will really test your ability to think under pressure.  However there does come a point where you start to predict the monsters spawn, its almost always after a major puzzle is solved or you've been left alone for too long. But despite any flaws this game may have they are minor to the all around solid design and atmosphere.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												are you looking for a game that can work as a costapatian aid? do you love horror that makes you poo your pants? well then you have come to the right game, amnesia the dark decent have hit that spot right on, the game is second to none when it comes to scaring you, and making all of your imaginasion do most of the work for you by audio and visualisation, this game has it all.friction games have made a marvel, from the beginning to the end, you will be bombarded with visual and audio that work perfectly to nurture your imaginasion to a state of paranoia.there is no weapons in the game, so if you see a monstrosaty, run bloody run and hide to the best of your abillaty, the only aid you have in the game is a lantern and some tinderboxes to light your way in this dark castle of terror, but oil is scarce, so use the lantern wisely, but if your thinking, "hey, lets just dont use the light so that we can hide in the shadows" not a chance, the monsters cant see you in the dark, but there is a sanety meter that goes haywhire if you stay in the dark for to long, and makes you halucinate, and if you go dot dot dot ont the sanety meter, the monsters will find you, so its a balance, amnesia is by far one of the greatest game i have played in a long time, so for me, its a solid 9/10

Posted: December 19, 2013
												Really cool game, very fluid controls that are unique yet can easily be adapted to. Captivating gameplay and intreguing story. Beside a haunted castle it is very unique in that respect. Although it isnt very scarry at all in my opinion, it is a good game for other reasons. Namly the story and the puzzles. To adress the horror aspect: It was unnerving, i wouldent say scarry at the begining. The phantom screams and creaking could get to you, yet after a while you realized there was nothing there. So, imo it is a sespencful puzzle game with a very good story, that is not given to you directly. You slowly aquire it via voice acted notes, that let you come to your own conclutions about what really happened.Would recomend to anyone who enjoys puzzles and a spooky story.

content:
Posted: October 12, 2016
												Custom stories are probably the way to go. They have a chance to be much more detailed and they can also feature custom content. Making your own story for others to enjoy is also a nice thing to do. There are so many out there... one for every person under the sun! <3Besides that, the original game has an interesting story rooted within old Europe (Prussia), and explores your fear of the paranormal. In addition to this, it uses zombie-like creatures to scare you while not being annoying rehashed enemies themselves. Some characters from this game have real-life counterparts, and the lore behind it shows that Frictional Games was on the right path before they created SOMA. I also recommend for you to check that game out, too. This game hasn't scared me lately because I have several hundred hours in it (lol), but it is still very fun to play and it has a great modding community online. I DID buy this during a sale, but it's well worth the money.

content:
Posted: October 11, 2016
												Very good game. The story is interesting, the enemies are creepy, the chase music is tense and keeps you leaning forward in your seat hoping you can outrun the monster right at your feet. The game does not look bad. The combination of a sanity meter and limited resources makes the game challenging, especially on the first play.  Amnesia: Justine is also very tense and scary. It is much shorter but still fun to play after you've beaten the main game and need a last taste of Amnesia. I recommend this game to fans of horror games and horror stories, especially H.P. Lovecraft. You will not be disappointed. I do not recommend this game to little kids who are not interested in story and soley want this game because it's so spooky! You will be very bored and disappointed. I rate this game 9/10

content:
Posted: April 17, 2011
												Amnesia, a 1st person horror-adventure, is one of the coolest (and scariest... let's not forget scariest) games I've played in a long while. There are no guns or other weapons of any kind. It's just you, locked in a creepy castle, doing whatever you can to survive to the end... which usually involves hiding and trying not to soil your pants too much. As a fan of old-school adventure games from the dawn of the genre, I very much appreciated this new modern take on things. The game has gotten lots of buzz since its release, and all of the praise is well-deserved, especially for such a small developer. If you like horror, mysteries and/or adventure games (and don't mind being scared out of your wits too much), Amnesia is a no-brainer. Two thumbs up!

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 14, 2015
												At a Glance: Amnesia: The Dark Descent is a Masterpiece of a horror game.  A worthy successor to Frictional Game's stellar Penumbra series, Amnesia keeps you watching your back and questioning yourself every time you go to open a door.  The gameplay is entertaining with its puzzles yet frightening as you play as our hero, Daniel, with no means of self defense.  The story is intriguing and keeps you motivated to solve puzzles and keep your sanity as you venture further into the deep walls of the Castle Brennenburg.  Extra Content:Not only did the team at Frictional Games create a free expansion for Amnesia called Amnesia: Justine, but the game contains a Custom Story function. This allows you to play countless community-made Amnesia Stories once you've installed them through Steam, Desura, or manually from ModDB.  The gameplay value is huge.Conclusion:  Amnesia: The Dark Descent is one of my personal favorite Horror Games of all time.  From the beautifully detailed castle environments to the immersive atmosphere and story, this is one game that horror fans won't want to pass up.

content:
Posted: June 17, 2016
												Amnesia: The Dark Descent is the pinacle of horror games for beginners. Always best when played with headphones on and up at a loudish volume, but not loud enough for your ears to bleed, leave that to public concert karaoke festivals.In Amnesia, you play as a young British man named Daniel who, well, has amnesia. He goes around finding notes and clues based on his previous thoughts, but as he collects all these things, he is simultaneousely being chased by an evil ghoulish spirit named The Manpig. This becomes more revealing of his name in the sequel, Machine For Pigs.Many young youtubers have gained exponential fame when playing this game on their let's play channels. These youtubers consist of popular names, such as Markiplier and PewDiePie.I love the setting of the game and the grim tone of it. Also the physics and ragdoll effects work amazingly. This game is a work of art in my opinion and I recommend it for anyone in the mood for a good scare or wanting to reach popularity on YouTube.

content:
Posted: January 15, 2014
												9/10Highlights: Experience, Atmosphere, Sound, and SoundtrackThe benchmark of virtual terror... This game is unlike most other survival-horror games out there. Instead of running through creepy environments with pistols and melee weapons, you're stuck with nothing but a lantern in Amnesia: the Dark Descent. This game forces you to be defenseless against the many horrific creatures within the Castle Brennenburg and because of this, you must utilize stealth-like strategies in order to bypass the monsters. On paper, the gameplay is bare-boned and easy, but what really hits the player hard is the looming fear of the unknown. Unless you've watched youtube videos or seen someone else play this game, you are going in unprepared for an environment that is unfamiliar. You are more likely to fear that which you do not see rather than what is evident.- The story is somewhat clever, however your only connection to the story is through multiple notes you find throughout the levels and several scripted flashbacks.- The game's strongest point is its emphasis on a consistently claustrophobic and dark atmosphere. This is also strengthened by the quality of sounds used within this game as they are top-notch and  fit perfectly within the stone-walled and echoey castle. Along with this, the soundtrack is absolutely fear-inducing and befitting for the environment presented.- The game's weakest point is some of the puzzle mechanics. Most of the puzzles do not require much thought to figure out, however, some can take longer than others and have a tendency to frustrate the player and draw them out of game's intended experience/atmosphere. There have been moments where I'd spend large amounts of time backtracking to find something that I may have missed.I purchased this game a long while back around when it first came out and have played through it multiple times along with player-made mods (some of which are even scarier) both solo and with groups. What I have found this game to be is the bar at which other survival horrors must meet in order to emphasize true quality in the genre. This is one game that I can always bring up in a conversation about video games since it really blurs the line between fantasy and reality.

content:
Posted: July 4, 2011
												"I don't know what's in there, but it's weird and♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥off whatever it is!" -John Carpenter's The Thing.Amnesia is a delightfully disturbing little horror story that takes place back in the 18th century. You awaken trapped inside a deserted castle, with no way out and no weapons, you can only run from one dark room to the next, trying to avoid the monstrosities that lurk the halls. Your only hope is to unearth this place's disturbing history if you want to survive the paranormal force that is chasing you, fighting to maintain your sanity as the darkness closes in. Amazingly atmospheric and excellently paced, Amnesia is a game that'll give you nightmares, and I love it!

content:
Posted: May 1, 2011
												Frictional Games is known as a small indie developer that has had previous success in its survival-horror Penumbra franchise. Their most recent release, Amnesia: The Dark Descent, should rightfully remove that trilogy from the throne and replace it with Amnesia. The Dark Descent is an absolutely fanstastic addition to FG's catalogue given its immersive atmosphere into a truly terrifying setting. The sound, graphics and cryptic story are first rate easily leaving behind any A-list horror titles in the dust. If you enjoy an engrossing atmosphere with excellent gameplay and don't mind having to change your trousers every once in awhile then Amnesia is a MUST HAVE!

Posted: November 5, 2011
												One of the most unique titles in recent memory, this small Indie game from Frictional Games is now an infamous phenomenon because of one simple fact: It is one of, if not the scariest game ever made. Amnesia is not only a scary game, it's also a game of high quality, capable of wholly immersing you into its' world, and easily making you part of the experience better than most games can. You owe it to yourself to play Amnesia, but be warned, it's not for the faint of heart. A masterpiece of a horror title, but only the bravest can make the dark descent.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 26, 2015
												I never played this game when it was being hyped, but i picked it up for free and it's actually a really good game.  The story was enough to keep me intrigued as it was slowly revealed to me through diary pages I found while exploring this enormous castle.  I think if this game didn't have the interesting story that it does I would never have finished it,  it's ultimately what kept me going.  The game was legitimately scary for awhile,  with monsters appearing in the darkest and scariest places of the castle,  and having to run and hide till they were out of sight.  There were even a few jump scares thrown in for good measure.  Although after awhile it stopped scaring me as I figured out how the monsters operated and found really simple ways to bypass them.  I highly recommend this game for anybody looking for a well thought out horror game,  I am glad I got it for free though because I can't justify the 22$ price tag for 7 hours of gameplay.

content:
Posted: September 17, 2015
												I played this game way back in 2011 or 2010 with 2 of my friends on skype. I know, the real balls play solo. But we really wanted to play it together.  I've finished it about 4 times in total with different friends (they needed to hold my hand  ;) ) but I swear to god, it was still damn scary.I have played quite a few horror games, and I must say Amnesia is one of the best atmospheric psycholocial horror i've ever played. Frictional Games are absolutely masters at it!It's not just jumpscares: it's the environment, the scenery, the distant screams and mumbling. The cracking and footsteps upstairs you hear continuesly around you. There are only slight hints that the enemy is nearby, it doesn't really tell you where to go or where it would come from. All you know what's going on is that you're in a dark room and you just wanna ♥♥♥♥ing light some candles because holy♥♥♥♥♥♥it's so dark here. :') but then you would signal a monster. Welp.I absolutely recommend this game to the horror fanatics and who love something psychological to it rather than just raw scary stuff and weird slimey stuff on the walls that's  all really forced. I swear, this game really does something to you. 5/5

content:
Posted: February 6, 2015
												A great story that references real-world history and personalities and has mind-blowing twists and turns.  All while scaring the living @#%! out of you.  Be prepared for a grueling playthrough in most cases, depending on how lucky you get with the randomized monster encounters.  Best played either with a lot of friends in a room together if you want to sleep well, or alone at night with headphones if you're a masochist that's prepared to stay up all night clutching a shotgun.  If you haven't played this game yet, you need to get with the program and do it.FAIR WARNING:  I've seen things in this game that I almost wish I never had.   Squeamish players should not, I repeat SHOULD NOT read all of the books and notes inside the torture chambers.  Human beings are horrifying creatures, and the game references actual historical torture practices and devices.  While none of the acts are shown on-screen, all of the "pre-recorded" sounds are there alongside the in-depth descriptions of what was done.  There's serious nightmare-fuel in there that's a lot more terrifying than any of the monsters.  Word to the wise.

												I like dark and creepy movies. I also like dark and creepy games. This one is definetly dark and creepy. Jump scare? Yes. Mind numbing Insanity? Indeed!And you are likely to wind up dead in the bowels of this manor, filled with secrets, a mysterious backstory and an empty mind. Piece for piece you gather clues what has happened, you gather clues and items to help you along. And there are things, that lurk in the darkness. And others that are only a figment of your own imagination, or so you hope - only to learn that you are not imagining those critters. I will give you a recomendation based on what is given in this game, not on the great graphics, the atmospheric sound or the gameplay.Are you looking for a horror game that offers a great deal of shock moments? Check!You love a game with the odds against you? Check!You are a horror novel fan, and especially romantic or supernatural horror? Check!You want to scream your brain out when the nightmare grasps your consciousness? Check!If you love horror games, you will love this game.

content:
Posted: January 4, 2014
												Don't let Amnesia's reputation fool you, this isn't just another jump-scary survival horror game! It has some of that, but the real scares are pretty varied and unpredictable, and the bulk of the game is actually progressed with puzzles. Overall I'd rate it a solid 4.5/5. There are a couple of puzzles that are pretty unintuitive, while others can feel a bit *too* easy, and the occasional encounters you're supposed to avoid being noticed by are more irritating than scary, but there's still a *lot* to recommend this game over others. The graphics are lovely, the audio and controls are immersive, a lot of the concepts and monsters are honestly unsettling, and the story is well-presented and enjoyable. Plus, even though there's basically no inherent replayability, the game is longer than you'd expect!Quick Pro: Dark, immersive atmosphere.Quick Con: Stealth gameplay segments are unsatisfying.

content:
Posted: September 18, 2015
												So, a lot of people call this game "the scariest game they've ever played", and go on and on about the scariness, but I am evidence that it is totally possible to play this game without really being scared! Most of the "horror" of this game is just gross things (read: fleshy things) in dark rooms, which isn't really horrifying, it's just... gross stuff in dark rooms, and if that's not something that bothers you, then you'll be just fine in this game. Honestly, Daniel (the main character) is much, much more freaked out than I am! If you play this with the idea that it's a video game, and play it the same way you'd play any other video game, then it's more fun than scary! It has a cool back story and very interesting puzzles, and interesting mechanics involving keeping Daniel's mental health from deteriorating by keeping him out of the dark (which he seems to be very afraid of), and from observing disturbing events. So this is not a game where you can just run from point a to point b, you really have to think and strategize about your movements and where you go/stand to keep Daniel in a functional state. It's pretty cool and I've not played anything quite like it before! Also, rather than fighting monsters, you have to make them go away, which is also quite interesting (though there were no monsters for the entire first hour of the game and that was a bit disappointing to me), by hiding in the dark, no less! And either action, getting too close to a monster, or hanging out in the dark, will lower Daniel's sanity, so it requires some careful planning and knowing when it will be okay to come out. As briefly mentioned earlier, the story is presented in a very cool way, Daniel gave himself amnesia at the beginning and you basically have it right along with him, as you obviously don't know anything that he used to know. And as the story unfolds its like unravelling a mystery. Very cool! I also found the game a bit educational, as it takes place in the 1800's and is faithful to the time period, so I was able to look up some of the objects that are in the game and learn about what they were. All in all, this was a very enjoyable experience for me, so I give it a full recommendation! I didn't find it as scary as most people seem to, but I enjoy the gameplay and find it to be a very unique experience. I've had a lot of fun!

												Frictional Games is known as a small indie developer that has had previous success in its survival-horror Penumbra franchise. Their most recent release, Amnesia: The Dark Descent, should rightfully remove that trilogy from the throne and replace it with Amnesia. The Dark Descent is an absolutely fanstastic addition to FG's catalogue given its immersive atmosphere into a truly terrifying setting. The sound, graphics and cryptic story are first rate easily leaving behind any A-list horror titles in the dust. If you enjoy an engrossing atmosphere with excellent gameplay and don't mind having to change your trousers every once in awhile then Amnesia is a MUST HAVE!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 18, 2014
"Hey there, so I like to play games that scare me."Oh cool, well you've picked the right ga-"Like, pants-♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ly scary. I don't want to be able to sleep."Y-yeah, sure. Like I was saying, this game would be perfect for y-"And I also like the odd puzzle or two to complete in the story"Okay, well you're in luck, because this has that t-"While I'm simultaneously ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ my pants"You have issues.So yes, Amnesia: The Dark Descent is quite a scary game. The scariest, in fact, that I have come across. You play as Daniel in this Survival Horror game, who wakes up in a castle with no memory of how he got there (bing! title!).Unlike horror games such as F.E.A.R, where you can defend yourself against monsters; here, you have no means of fighting back. It's a frightening game of hide-and-seek. And the fear trickles in, it doesn't reveal everything straight away, so the anticipation of running into a monster really eats away at you.It's not just your health that you have to keep track of, but your sanity. If you remain in the dark too long, or look at something that doesn't make any rational sense, your sanity starts to deplete. This makes your screen blurry, and your controls less responsive, making for a harder experience. Thankfully, you've got a lantern and can find oil and tinderboxes along the way to keep you in the light.The story is actually compelling, the gothic artstyle is perhaps outdated now, but fits the game perfectly. You may quit due to fear and frustration from the few puzzles you come across, but this is definitely worth pushing through to reach the end, where there are some rather confronting torture chambers.

content:
Posted: January 24, 2015
 Positive + Downright disturbing story, with notes obtainable throughout the game only further detailing gruesome details of events that have taken place+ Great voice acting all-around (most notably Sam A. Mowry as Alexander)+ The well-developed physics engine allows for some entertaining puzzles and interaction with the environment+ Some good lighting effects help to punctuate the necessity of keeping out of the dark. Negative - Some poor gameplay mechanics: most notably the sanity system, which only sets out to hinder your progress rather than immerse you into the game; and even when I liberally used the lantern throughout the game, I was never close to running out of oil nor tinderboxes- While the game does manage to retain a fearful atmosphere for the most part, in actuality there are only around 5 or so enemies that can actually harm/kill you, which makes the possibility of death inconsequential and reduces the overall ‘scariness’ of the game Verdict “Amnesia: The Dark Descent does manage to effectively replicate a scary atmosphere and tell a good story, which many gamers have recognised. However, the game would have been much better suited in another format (most notably a book), as it seems that--in its current form--it is more of an interactive story than an actual game. Nevertheless, the overwhelmingly unnerving experience alone is worth a playthrough.” 7/10 TJBs

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 30, 2015
												I can grudgingly recommend this game. While it certainly works and it's enjoyable, this game is one that is overhyped and filled with plotholes while relying on darkness and a rather comical design of wandering enemies to make you feel afraid. It's a lot of fluff and icing you have to dig through to get to this cake. Once you get to the cake, it's not much of a cake. It's a basic horror story where you have to solve puzzles, dodge the enemy, and defeat the big baddie.Mark my words, I was never afraid. Not once was I afraid. The suggested darkness did nothing but cause irritation for someone with poor eyesight and the game relies too much on the player not being able to see anything to raise panic and alarm. I find this to be a poor thing to rely on. There's also the matter of the story. It starts off very strong with Daniel's expedition having gone horribly wrong and seeking help from Alexander, but begins to slip up. We're told much of Daniel's life via loading screens rather than in game and Alexander's own desires are hardly explained, leaving this game feeling rushed. At the end of the game, I feel like I understand nothing because I learned more about Agrippa than I learned about Daniel and Alexander and that's a shame for me, considering I'm playing as Daniel and I'm trying to stop Alexander.The "multiple endings" are hardly endings at all. You get some different dialogue and very little of a difference for your efforts of having gone through the extra lengths to get your "good" ending. One would probably expect a little more than swirling clouds. Perhaps we could have had a visit from Daniel's sister or something a bit more meaningful, but I suppose it is what it is. It's hardly anything that makes a difference. Something else that didn't make a difference was the sanity bar. I found Daniel didn't draw as much attention to himself as the game warned me. What it did do was create more "horror" for the screen. I had more fiendish enjoyment at hearing Daniel squeak at falling into bodies or at paintings that were now twisted, but no patrols ever were drawn to my location. I doubt that's because I'm good at playing.The puzzles, however, are something to be enjoyed. They're just the right difficulty and while sometimes they are headscratchers, they don't really take all-too-long to figure out. Hiding mechanics are delightful and I found myself with a sick sort of satisfaction to hear Daniel react to the twisted, disgusting world around him.Music was perfect and sometimes I'd sit in the hub areas (safe from monsters) and listen to the music for a bit while taking a break from the game. It was just nice to relax to for a moment. You know, before running away from patrols of those twisted, fleshy beings for an umpteenth time. A little mood music before running off to my death and whatnot. Graphics were beautiful in such a grand and yet gruesome castle. Sometimes it felt like these levels could have been longer and showed off these lovely (yet now a bit dated!) graphics. Level design is satisfying in this game and your objectives are always very clear.But they're very clear and boring. Get item or get to the exit. Dodge the bad guys. If you die, the bad guy despawns. They'll chase you, but if you mess up, you don't get chased again. It's hardly a challenge. Except the water levels. In that case, those are a bit of a pain.The main game has a lot of my gripes, but I am partial to the DLC Justine. It's a bit more difficult, has a stronger story, and is much more terrifying. It forces you to make and live with choices while altering the outcome of your game. This game of morality is what a good Amnesia game could have been, but TDD is rather weak....But if you are the average gamer, which you probably are, this game will do as it advertises. It'll scare you. You'll be playing a survival horror game. You'll enjoy yourself. You probably won't notice the gaping plotholes. I still say play Justine over TDD because she's much more interesting than Daniel is. You'll be tempted to let him die a few times.I won't judge you if you do. In fact, I let him die multiple times. On purpose. It felt great.

												The monsters in this game are great, OP even. You cannot attack them, only hide or run from them. Even just looking at them makes you slowly go insane. The various puzzles and the way you interact with the objects around you are quite nice as well.The story is okay. The few times you are being chased are great. However, the final encounter, if you can even call it that, is quite awful; you'd expect a boss, a fight, something, but instead you get to knock over some pylons and hear some naked zombie complain about it.Also, you can't really die in this game; if you do, you will respawn close by with no penalty whatsoever, which is not very cool.Overall 6/10

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 9, 2016
SummaryAmnesia: The Dark Descent is a first person exploration/puzzle game with heavy emphasis on atmosphere. If you're looking for an unsettling 7-8 hour horror experience that doesn't rely on jump scares, this game should be an obvious choice.In detailWithout giving anything away, the game is about exploring a dark castle and the story is delivered in flashbacks and in random notes and diary entries you find scattered around. Apart from one particular puzzle towards the end, majority of them didn't take me too much time to figure out. The character makes helpful notes when you explore places and you always have either a new area to explore or a note/memento/diary entry that guides you what is needed to achieve next.There are enemies, environmental hazards and fall damage that tick away your health, but it can be restored by using potions. However, the more interesting game mechanic is the sanity meter; Losing sanity is tied to various things like looking at creepy things, staying too long in the dark etc. and solving puzzles restores it. Going insane affects on how the character controls and causes all kinds of creepy visual effects.Most of the tension and horror comes from the sound design, being in the dark unable to defend yourself and losing your sanity. There are a lot of optional light sources, but you need to manage a resource to decide which of them you actually want to ignite. Rest of the time you're relying on a lantern with a limited oil supply and it forces you to move at a quicker pace than you might be comfortable with.I almost gave up playing this 2-3 hours in, after a couple of the first major sections, thinking I had seen all it had to offer. I started writing this review at that point basing it around the start of the game and what I had seen so far. Thankfully I didn't quit as the scariest stuff was right around the corner.RecommendationI think the game should've maybe been an hour or two shorter as I found it losing me a bit towards the very end. Still, I can appreciate the things it does get right and give it a solid recommendation. There aren't too many games around that manage to get under your skin like Amnesia: TDD does. For a better experience, make sure to at least use a proper gamma setting. I also recommend playing in the dark and possibly during night time, without distractions.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 8, 2014
												Amnesia the Dark Decent is a puzzle/ horror game made by Frictional games.  In amnsia you must avoid monsters, solve very challenging puzzles and use the environment to your advantage as you try to remember who you are and achieve your goals.Amnesia has a very good story line in that is keeps you scared and interested with it's dark and morbid theme. Through the whole game there are also many back storys viewed in notes and flash backs to explain what happened so long ago.In this game you can only run or hide while in other horror games you can fight this one you can not, you must use your brain, senses and wits to survive. The AI is very well done it will keep you on your toes, as it attempts to hunt you and it’s good at what it does. I have not seen a single glitch in the game yet with the AI.The physics are mostly perfect, you can use the objects around you to make sounds to escape danger and also for barricading or solving complex puzzles.The soundtrack suits the environment and atmoshphere well, it brings out the best in the horrer experience and it really helps to immerse ones self into the game. This can also be usefull as it can signal the approch of an enamy or other things. The sound design is all so fairly accurate to, if you use your ears you can hear where the monsters are and the genral direction to. This also works well with the throwing of objects and contraptions as they sound unique and of good quality.What also makes this good is that it does not rely heavily on jump scares, rather it messes with your mind instead. It makes you imagine there’s an enemy round the corner, behined you or in a room close by. This means that the game uses your own imagination to scare you, as it plays mind games to make you jumpy. Graphics wise it has a unique medevil style to it well detailed with plenty of varied and well thought out locations and enviroments, each haveing it's own theme and style to it as well.One of my grudges is that there is not much variety in monsters, this can mean that monsters can get less scary or get more easy to predict as time goes on, since there is only 3-4. However the monsters that are present work and act very diffrently from each other, haveing unique sounds mechanics and aesthetics to each of them.The puzzles are varied and complex from the basics to finding a hidden item, up to working out how to fix advanced machinery and other things. This also ties in with the ability to maniplulate objects, as mentiond befor you will need to do this to compleat some puzzles.Personally I got scared over and over again I love this game, because it gives you a real sense of fear and no way to fight back unlike other games, like dead space or resident evil where you can shoot the monster and lose the fear factor quickly. SPOLIER ALERTMy last grudge is with the endings in which there are 3 one I find to be satisfiying, the other to  feeling like copy pastes of one another with only slight varation, but this is just my opnion on it. This is just my opinion but Overall amnesia the dark decent is a great game filled with horror suspence and fright, if you love horror then I definitely recommend you play this game and it’s not too pricey ever well worth the buy. I give it an 8.5 out of 10 I would rate it higher but there is a lack of monster types and the endings give this a lower score.

content:
Posted: November 14, 2013
												Amnesia is a decent puzzle game. I say puzzle because I wasn't horrified by this game. At all. There were also times that I managed to bug out enemies from my sight. If you're used to Japanese Horror and planning to play this game, prepare to be disappointed since you won't really find yourself to be scared. I am thankful that it doesn't reset my progress (like Outlast) and the checkpoints allows me to streamline my progress and continue with the story. I enjoyed the game despite some weird puzzles and recommend it.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 7, 2014
												Truly one of the scariest games I've ever played. The atmosphere is tense and ominous from start to finish. I also found the exploration, resource management, and puzzle-solving to be genuinely satisfying. The insanity meter and monster evasion tactics necessary to survive make the game truly terrifying when trapped in a tight spot, though the monster variety and frequency of the main game I feel could have improved a bit. The addition of custom stories and smaller additional campaigns, however, solves this issue by adding a ton variety with numerous different scenarios to the to the mix. This is a must buy for any survival-horror fan.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 11, 2012
												Amnesia captures the essence of what it is to be terrifying.  You're not a one-man army.  You're not a space marine.  You're not even a guy with just a few hours of martial arts class.  You're just an ordinary person with no memory of who he once was trying to uncover the clues behind his past (yeah I know it sounds cliche, but this is one game that makes it work really well).  You have only one defense: run.  Run as fast as you can and hide.  If it's a scary game you want then look no further.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 26
												You don't often get a horror game that is genuinely terrifying without throwing a slew of cheap jump scares at you. But when you do, you get one of the greatest horror games ever created. You get Amnesia: The Dark Descent (try out the extra campaign thing called Justine, that's good too. Just try to stay away from A Machine for Pigs)

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 18, 2014
"Hey there, so I like to play games that scare me."Oh cool, well you've picked the right ga-"Like, pants-♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ly scary. I don't want to be able to sleep."Y-yeah, sure. Like I was saying, this game would be perfect for y-"And I also like the odd puzzle or two to complete in the story"Okay, well you're in luck, because this has that t-"While I'm simultaneously ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ my pants"You have issues.So yes, Amnesia: The Dark Descent is quite a scary game. The scariest, in fact, that I have come across. You play as Daniel in this Survival Horror game, who wakes up in a castle with no memory of how he got there (bing! title!).Unlike horror games such as F.E.A.R, where you can defend yourself against monsters; here, you have no means of fighting back. It's a frightening game of hide-and-seek. And the fear trickles in, it doesn't reveal everything straight away, so the anticipation of running into a monster really eats away at you.It's not just your health that you have to keep track of, but your sanity. If you remain in the dark too long, or look at something that doesn't make any rational sense, your sanity starts to deplete. This makes your screen blurry, and your controls less responsive, making for a harder experience. Thankfully, you've got a lantern and can find oil and tinderboxes along the way to keep you in the light.The story is actually compelling, the gothic artstyle is perhaps outdated now, but fits the game perfectly. You may quit due to fear and frustration from the few puzzles you come across, but this is definitely worth pushing through to reach the end, where there are some rather confronting torture chambers.

content:
Posted: May 8, 2013
												I bought this Indie game at a sale price of  $4.99 or  75% off. I recommend you try to get it at a sale price if you can.This is a story unlike any you will ever  play.Set in the early 1800's Its not a FPS but a story of survival and all thats evil in man .Many gamers say it is the scariest  game they have ever played.This game is not for younger kids.There is blood ,monsters ,torture,and very graphic death scenes.You are not trying to fight off the evil but to survive and get your redemption at the end.Many puzzles to solve that are challenging but not so hard that you will be stuck or to frustrated.I played the game in just over 18 hours to finish with multiple endings. I found it very interesting and was in a trance at times as I followed the story .I took many screenshots that may be spoilers !!Played for a second time around for the new achievements and still just as good as 3 years ago.The added achievments give it some added challenge and the 'Justine' DLC was also a nice short story. Of course I still couldnt resist taking many screenshots many the same as beofre but with a larger friends list I had to share this horror game!

content:
Posted: August 22, 2014
												As someone  that will scream at the most predictable of jump scares I hate horror games. My friends make a point of gifting me horror anything just to constantly remind me they are willing to watch me play for 'support'. And that is exactly how Amnesia The Dark Descent appeared in my library. One lazy Sunday afternoon I felt particularly brave; headset - check, buddy on chat to play through with - check, all lights on and closed doors - check. I was hyperventilating from the very "no no nooo way go away" to the last.Highly recommend a change of underwear before, during and after playing.

content:
Posted: October 30, 2014
												The game that is right up there with the original Resident Evil for fundamentally altering my perception on what a scary game could be. Unending, godless nightmarish tension combined with some of the most brilliant sound design in any game create an amazing level of immersion. I think that even people who don't care for horror games should at least try it out, and it's mandatory for those that do.

content:
Posted: September 14, 2015
												Reviewing horror classics this time.The game, that changed the way, scary games were made... the father of Outlast !What makes this scary?1. The Atmosphere - The atmosphere is very tense. The game takes place in dark old castle, which appears empty (oh it is not :D). Authors made the sounds very frightening and whole game makes you feel like something is following you - you may just get very paranoid.2. The Unknown - Why am i here? Who... or what is after me? WTF WAS THAT SOUND? thats the questions that will be very slowly answered.3. Defenslessness - You just have no way to fight back, your only option is to hide. Enemies are uncommon in this game, which just makes their encounter surprising and scary and relies on your quick reaction.Worth a try, but note, that this game is focused on story. Reading long notes is big part of the game - some takes you to flashback and some will hint you the solution to some puzzles, you will find along the way. There are no weapons, you will not be killing anyone in this game. They, however, may kill you :P.8/10, you will never visit any castles ever again.

content:
Posted: September 15, 2015
												Why am I writing this up? It's Amnesia. It's the game that everyone points to first when someone asks "What's a scary game?" People that have never played it recommend it to people who will buy it and never play it. What am I even doing here?The truth is, I needed a reason to revisit this one. I'm a terribly jumpy person and genuinely scary games can wear me out good. The first time I played Amnesia, I never even made it to a monster. I knew I needed to give it another go and this was the perfect time to do it. And while I was playing, a thought occurred to me. Amnesia's been around for years at this point. How does it hold up in a post-Alien: Isolation world?Amnesia casts you, unsurprisingly, as an amnesiac in a drafty old castle back in the 1800s. You soon find a missive from yourself, assuring you that you didn't want those memories anyway and there's someone in the castle you really ought to kill. As you begin exploring the darkened, crumbling halls, you find that there are other residents of the castle that are none too pleased to see you. There's no fighting in this one, it's pure stealth or fleeing. The cornerstone of Amnesia's gameplay, much like Penumbra before it, is sanity. Looking at monsters, seeing freaky things happening, and being in the dark make you lose sanity. Of course, if you stand there in front of a torch, the things that want to turn your insides into outsides will have an easy time spotting you. Encounters with monsters are all about balancing your stealthy skulking against your dwindling sanity, which is only restored by progressing through the game. It's a finite resource system like food in Lone Survivor, and works to layer urgency on top of your horror. I must admit it's a bit of a bother here though, because it puts some irritating visual effects on you when it gets terribly low.The sanity effects are about the only misstep in the aesthetics, though. The graphics still hold up and manage to be rich and varied while still maintaining the dark, oppressive atmosphere. The level design is simple but effective, sending you through lavish halls and crumbling cellars and stranger places still, pacing out the frights and creatures. The big standout here though is the sound design. There is a lot more going on here than in most games, with your character making all sorts of breathing sounds and whimpers, footsteps for everyone being accurate to the surface that produces them, and even light sources making their own realistic ambient sounds. The castle itself is full of creepy sounds as well, most being apropos of nothing, but that just makes it all the more effective when it DOES signal something.I was very pleased with the pacing of the game, and found it had little to no contrivances to get you where it wanted you to be. Enemy encounters are infrequent enough to keep you on edge when they're not around, and absolutely terrify you when they are. Dealing with them is obviously less involved than in Alien: Isolation but much more free-form than, say, Outlast. I could see some of the terror being lost if you have to repeat certain sections a few times, but the game is balanced well enough with pacing and items that it shouldn't be a concern unless you're really trying to pull back the curtain for yourself.To my surprise, I found myself getting scared more often with this than in Alien. For me, Alien is much more about constant tension and the battle of wits with the xenomorph, whereas Amnesia is more about the terror of being helpless and confused. Not many games have managed to pull off the powerless protagonist angle without it becoming grating, but Amnesia owns it. Simple sounds and sudden visual effects will chill you to the bone, not as cheap jump scares but as payoffs to the incredible atmosphere the game maintains at all times. I feel confident in saying that no matter how far the genre progresses, Amnesia will always have a place of honor among the games that truly terrify.

content:
Posted: August 25, 2014
												The first thing newcomers need to understand is that this game is NOT the sequel to Blue's Clues as some would suspect. But instead buckle in with your kids for a fun-filled family shooting game in the vein of Wii Sports and Mario Kart. You play as Daniel, a man who is lost in the castle looking for his Princess, Alexander. This game is definitely taking gay rights and marriage equality to new heights by introducing young children to this matter. Unfortunately, your princess is in another castle (or sanctum) and so you have to defeat Bowsers new plucky goons, the Duckfaces, along with the Creakarms in order to find him. There are various fun puzzles you have to complete, such as redirecting water in the sewer to get a silly man to stay quiet and stop disturbing the eco-system. All in all it teaches kids fantastic modern values and is not only ahead of its time in terms of content but also in gameplay.It is the first family game since Freddi Fish to allow users to make their own custom stories. Maybe you need to teach your kids the value of honesty and kindness? Valve is way ahead of you with its custom story Justine, but you can design your own with the knowledge of scripting and programming! Forget robots, Amnesia is the future.I was personally disappointed with the lack of female characters but understandably, Ubisoft is to blame.11/10 game, definitely start with your kids young.

content:
Posted: October 6, 2016
												I... don't get it. This is supposed to be one of the greatest horror games of all time? Did I go into it with too high expectations? Did playing Frictional's other games first desensitize me?My problems with Amnesia can be easily explained when you look at the second sentence on it's Steam page:"A game about immersion, discovery and living through a nightmare."Immersion. I had no issues immersing myself in Penumbra's universe. SOMA, despite having a very talkative protagonist, was still a relatable character, and I had no issues seeing myself in his shoes. Amnesia, however, is based around a very gimmicky sanity mechanic. It sounds like a good idea in theory, especially considering the Lovecraftian themes the game is touching on, but in practice it only served to break immersion. How am I supposed to find this world scary, or even take it seriously when the POV character is waaaaay more scared of the wind blowing open a door than I am? Not just scared, cowering in fear. Crawling and spasming on the ground over nothing and I'm just sitting here going... what the ♥♥♥♥, dude?Discovery. SOMA had no lighting issues. Penumbra was very dark at places, but I never ran out of glowsticks or flashlight batteries. Amnesia, on the other hand? Not only is it much worse lit than Penumbra, but light sources are extremely scarce. How am I supposed to know anything about my environment, or discover anything, when I can't see a ♥♥♥♥ing thing? Not only that, but the game discourages you from spending time in the darkness. It increases your insanity. So here I am bumping between walls, trying to find my way out of a room while my character is having a panic attack because he is literally afraid of the dark?Living through a nightmare. I'll give the game that. Playing this thing was a nightmare. Not a fun nightmare either. Not even a scary one. Just an underwhelming and thoroughly boring one.No, I do not reccomend this game. Penumbra: Overture had a few problems but I loved every minute of it, Penumbra: Black Plague is a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ed masterpiece. Penumbra: Requiem exists. SOMA is very, very good, as I mentioned in my review of it. Amnesia... is an extremely overhyped pile of♥♥♥♥♥♥ It's got nothing on Frictional's other work.

												This game is on top of it's notch, one of the few horror games that acctually gets you to the scary atmosphere as you cross the castle within Daniel's nightmare and spirit. You hear these chilly footsteps behind you and you run away, oh there's a monster lurking in the dark or why not these funny puzzles in which you have to use your mind to get through secret pathways among the darkness inside the castle. The voices within and the banging on the doors, the discovery of shadowy corridors or rooms in which you sit silently and await what happens. The bodies in which appears from thin air and blood is all over the floor, the disgusting tools in which you need to open a head through surgery and play a doctor. Until the shadowy orb in which you need to establish, the only way to escape the castle of death. Through meaning of life, to the midst of evil, you walk your path and salute your enemies through the dwellings and sounds from the walls, this shivering experience, between life or death in which haunts you from a beautiful beginning to an evil end, escape Daniel, escape, you are not worthy of this nightmare, survive. In his memories you are, in this game you are, alone finding the dark evil through shadows, if you haven't played this game I'd recommend you do, if you are a true horror lover - get it! 7/10 apart from graphics.

content:
Posted: April 10, 2014
												This is such a fantastic game - even though I'm having problems with it, no matter how many times I die to monsters (or end up getting stuck inside a room) I just want to keep playing. In fact, I'm doing a series of highlights videos on my Youtube channel where I'm playing through this pretty much completely blind. I'm not picking up any notes or journals or diaries; I'm not reading anything, and I'm still having a blast with it when I'm wandering around not knowing what to do. I guess that's just another great thing about this game; they managed to make a coherent story using only flashbacks, so that even without reading any of the important stuff I still kind of know why I'm doing what I'm doing. I'm even looking forward to finishing this first playthrough so I can go back on my own and read everything up, pick up all the details I missed and see how much that changes the story.This is the first part of my series if you want to check it out: 


YouTube™ Video: Amnesia: The Dark Descent - Let's Play Highlights - Part 1 

			Views: 34		

			Wherein I skip every note, journal, memento, and diary while playing Amnesia: The Dark Descent. If you enjoyed the video, leave a like - it really helps!

Posted: November 23, 2013
												This is the horror game you are looking for. Play this with headphones alone at night and you will experience a fear no other games or movies can give you. At the most intense moments, it's hard not to quit the game and leave the room in utter fear. You can't simply fight the monsters and ghosts in this game, so you will have to be careful not being spotted or not to make too much sound, or esle they'll come after you... and if they do, you need to run as fast as possible, while under the constant pressure of not going insane. If you are the kind of person looking for the scariest of games, this is the game for you. With a long, dark main story and a million DLC packs and user-created levels, the gameplay only ends when you're hiding under your bed, after smashing your PC in utter terror and fear.

content:
Posted: July 5, 2011
												I'll be very honest with it. Out of all the horror games I have played so far, this is the only TRUE survival horror. Games like Dead Space and others, they focus on ACTION as much as they focus on environment or atmosphere. But in this game, Amnesia, you get NO weapons. There is no action. The only weapon you get in this game are your feet that you can only use to RUN for your life. Trust me, this game will never scare you with high volume sounds (like other horror games do). It's the atmosphere, environment and situation that scares you in this game. If you like horror games, give it a try, I am sure you will like it. It will change the way of your thinking about horror games.

content:
Posted: April 20, 2014
												The infamous Amnesia. Driven by a dark and twisted storyline, backed by a soundtrack that is bound to give you the chills, Amnesia is everything you could ask for in a horror game.Introduction:Amnesia is a first person survival horror game set in a dark and mysterious castle environment.The plot takes place in 1893 where a young man from London, Daniel, finds himself awakened in the great halls of the Prussian Brennenburg Castle with no recollections of himself, his past or his current purpose. The only objects that guide Daniel in his journey are hand-written notes that he has written to himself, such as the one he finds in the beginning of the game. Controls and Gameplay:The most powerful feature in the game is the absence of items, such as weapons and armor. You are alone and defenseless. Only equipped with a lantern, run by a limited supply of fuel, your goal is to explore and uncover the dark secrets of castle Brenneburg. This is a core feature of the game, as it makes your journey through the castle perilous and terrifying.  Aside from the traditional health bar, your character has a sanity meter. Sanity is reduced if you spend too much time in the dark, and loss of sanity will progressively make your screen indistinct and blurry. Puzzles and other obstructions are also present in the game. They are, however, not difficult and are sometimes a more than welcome "time-out" in the intense horror, while at other times they participate in making the game more hectic and intense. In terms of control, they are working as intended and do not obstruct the player in his quest through the dark.Graphics:The graphics in the game are slightly dated. This is not a huge minus, as the graphics actually enhance the intense sensation of dread that is omnipresent in the game. Sound:The soundtrack subliminally emphasizes the mood of the game. It intensifies frightening moments and sooths you in safe zones. It sometimes disappears completely, leaving your character's frantically beating heart as the only sound...Replayability:As a consequence of the game's linear storyline, multiple playthroughs are not of interest. Once you have played through the game once, you have seen most of the content there is. Conclusion:Amnesia: The Dark Descent is a unique first person horror game driven by its compelling story and simple gameplay. Experience the intense and thrilling game equipped with only a lantern and your courage and uncover the dark secrets of Castle Brennenburg.  Recommendable: 10/10

												A fascinating little game.  At its absolute best, it delivers an exceedingly unsettling experience; at some point, you'll almost certainly find yourself cowering in a dark corner hoping desperately that something doesn't kill you and balancing the warm comfort of a candle against the risk something will come around the corner and rip your face off.  At its worst, it's a slow puzzler with sometimes-illogical requirements.Still, as a short, play-it-in-two-solid-sittings game, it's hard to top the  feel it delivers.  Well worth the 6-8 hours it'll take to finish.

												My favorite horror game. Creepy, disturbing and will make you jump out of your seat if you're willing to play at night. The mansion is huge and very easy to get lost in, and figuring out how to progress can be challenging at times. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 8, 2014
												Amnesia is probably one of my favourite games of all time and cetainly my favourite horror title of all time. The game itself plays very well and provides a very good atmosphere and mood. The enemies are always dangerous and always pose a threat to the player since you only have the capacity to outrun them over short distances and long distances will result in you being caught and likely killed. The games scare factor varies based on the player I myself didn't find it scary however it was tense and immersive and I enjoyed the experiece a lot.The games visuals are rather dated however, the lighting could use some touching up and some of the textures look as if they are from a very old game. However this didn't seem to ruin the immersion for me as its possible to interact with almost every object within the game world such a levers, candles, torches, barrels, crates and books to name a few, even those objects that aren't relevant are able to be interected with. This adds an extra layer of depth to the gameplay as it gets the player thinking about what is needed to complete certain sections and puzzles within the game. I was also quite impressed with the storyline and the way it was told as the notes system and being able to read into it by picking them up throughout the game allows for various interpretations of the story and also allows players to connect with it at their own pace. The average amount of play time it takes to complete the game I feel is also worth it for the price as it is a very enjoyable time and can potentially be played through again dependent on the players view of the game. This game also incorporates a few good mechanics such as the depleting lantern oil and insanity. This adds to the difficultly and fits in with it being in the survival horror genre. It could also signficantly alter the way some players move through the game.Overall: Fantastic, 90/100

Posted: January 15, 2014
												There aren't many horror games that and truly make you feel hesitant to play them not because they're bad games but because they truly keep you on edge. Amnesia: The Dark Descent is one of those games, and yes, I admit that I completely broke down at one point for fear that a monster would show up and slice up my back.Unfortunately, if you think about it for a while, the monsters become quite predictable and easy to avoid. When this happens, the horror element is lost, but it won't be until about 3/5 through the game before this happens. Still, the game itself and the occasional wonderful custom stories for it make it a worthy purchase.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 14, 2014
												I had big doubts about this game for a long time... No weapons, no way to fight or defend, nothing... how could that be entertaining?...I was so wrong that I've had to reevaluate how I look at everything.  Starting Amnesia I immediately felt a sense of uneasiness and bit of paranoia creeping through my body.  At first I thought, "Oh, its only cause it's dark and the sounds are atonal and creepy.. Get over it you wimp."  But the story continued to disturb me more and more and as I crept through the cold walls of Brennenburg Caslte, listening to the pathetic moans of some poor unknown souls trapped god knows where,  I actually started to panic a little bit.  I haven't felt that since I played Silent Hill as a child.  The rush of fear, the paralyzing feeling of your blood pumping furiously between your parts with abandon, unchecked and unbalanced...   This is not a game, It's an experience and so few games deliver such an immersion as to leave you physically shaking Never did I exepect to be brought back to the feeling that hiding under my blanket from the monsters in the dark brought me.  I will forever be marked by Amnesia.

content:
Posted: January 7, 2014
												X/10I'm not going to give this game a rating because frankly, that would be missing the point. Amnesia is a game, that is also not a game. It's a grand story meant to be immersed in. It creates a decent immersion of psychological horror in tandem with an impressive artistic display. This is not something for people to "brave through, beat, and brag about". It even tells you in the opening screens. I see a lot of hate coming down on this game as well as praise. And I just see a sea of people who missed the point. For those who liked it and missed the point, I suppose as long as you had fun I can't really argue. But at the same time you are singing the wrong praises. "Scariest game ever" is not what I would use to describe this. For those who disliked it and missed the point, I see a lot of "I didn't even beat it" comments followed or preceded by "it wasn't even that scary". Once again I will refer you to the opening scene where it blatantly tells you it is not meant to be played to complete. And you also can't really be upset about buying it because even the description reads "A game about immersion, discovery and living through a nightmare". Those who DID get the point, whether they liked or disliked it, understood and either did or did not enjoy the story. And they have very valid arguments.Now for those who are looking into this game / have not played it, I would remind you to take great heed that this game is NOT meant to be the scariest game ever. It is meant to be a chilling but greatly immersive story. If you are looking for a great story where you can live through and make decisions of survival for the sake of learning what happens next, not knowing or even remotely caring when it will end. This is definitely the game for you. However if you came here looking for "THE SCARIEST GAME EVAR DOOD ZOMG !!!!1!1!!!1 I'M GONNA BEAT IT SO FAST BRO" Then you should probably just move along.

content:
Posted: April 16, 2011
												Why is Amnesia so fantastic? It breaches the mindless, scripted scares that encompass other modern horror games today through a unique approach. This game throws you into a dark world where you remember nothing about where you are or why you are there, except that there is an unknown shadow chasing you as you try to decipher your purpose. Sitting in the dark causes you to hallucinate and slowly lose your mind, and you can die simply from looking at a monster for too long. The fear of the unknown, immersive ambience, and tense motifs are what scare the hell out of anyone attempting to play this game.

content:
Posted: January 18
												Amnesia is a pants sh*tting experience (nearly) throughout the whole game. It revived survival horror and brought it into the mainstream......however......once you discover the pattern behind the monster encounters, it's over. As in, the tension disappears and the fear factor becomes non-existent. In addition, the main protagonist's reactions are way overdone. He gets a seizure and hyperventilates each time a book falls off the shelf. It's not scary, it destroys immersion and makes the protagonist seem like a total wuss, especially when my own reaction to said book is a resounding 'meh'. I recommend it still since, other than horror, it can be an entertaining adventure game.For those curious, I will write about the pattern down below.*SPOILERS*It's not hard to discover the pattern, unfortunately.- The monster spawns are entirely scripted. They spawn very often once you take a puzzle item or solve a puzzle. Rarely when you enter a room.- To prevent from being killed, close the door to the room the puzzle or item are in before doing what you need to do. When the monster spawns, it starts attacking the door and gives you time to hide.- To hide, just break the line of sight. You don't even have to enter a dark area.- Keep being hidden until the monster music stops playing. Once this occurs, the monster literally despawned, i.e. it vanished, disappeared. You can now run around freely until a next monster spawns.There are one or two exceptions where the monster is already there, has a defined patrol route, and does not despawn.

content:
Posted: May 8, 2015
												Back when I first got this game I wouldn't really commit myself to it, for I thought it was indeed too scary for me and it drained me a lot. Then a month after that I decided I would try to beat it.. no guides, no cheats of course.  Well, it's a great experience. I particularly loved the voice acting, which is superb. Furthermore the music is excellent. There are moments when it makes you feel at ease and peaceful for just a few minutes before making you want to crouch under the desk and sob a bit. Even though it was rather shorter than I expected you definitely have to play it if you love horror. Lights off and a headset should be mandatory though. You will want to immerse in the story and the atmosphere as much a possible. Get it? YES.8/10

Posted: April 21, 2012
												If you want to be scared ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, this is the game. The ambiance and mood can be frightening, even when there is no immenent danger. Play in the dark, with headphones, alone. You will see. The main story line had medium replay value, but many many MANY custom stories are available which can be just as scary, or scarier. Endless fun and scares to be had here. If you want it to be less hardcore, you can join a skype call with your friends, share your screen, and let them help you out and enjoy your screams. Having a friendly voice in the background lessens the fear factor. Overall, I give this game an A++ for pulling the purpose off well, having little to no glitches, and having ( nearly ) endless free custom stories.
