Amnesia: The Dark Descent ReviewPositiveAtmosphereMusicSoundsStyle and graphicsGood horror (really scary)StoryEnding(s)Overall gameplayExplorationCustom storiesNegativeSome puzzlesSome things you need to do aren't clear (even if you read the notes)Too much somewhat useless reading (some find this positive)No VR supportConclusionATDD is a really great, atmospheric, horror game with a interesting story. If this is one of your first horror games you will be scared sh*tless. The good thing about the game is that it isn't all about jumpscares like many other horror games. Also, there are no cutscenes which makes it more immersive and adds to the horror experience. I'd recommend you to buy this instantly.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 4, 2016
												Alrighty, another review! Amnesia: The Dark Descent is one of those games that you see everywhere and wonder how creepy/eerie/scary it might be. Well you just come to the right place if you want to either♥♥♥♥♥♥your pants or learn a fascinating yet gory story. You wake up as Daniel and have no recolation as to where or how you got to where you are when waking up. As the story progresses (and I will try not to have any spoilers) you pick up notes and random journal entries that you had written before passing out and waking up in the beginning. As your memory gets better, you realize you had been working for an evil mastermind named Alexander who kidnapps victims and tortures them to be "experiments". Once found out this, you do whatever you can to stop Alexander. The rest is up to you to find out, besides everyone likes suprises. Now, when playing this game I was scared within 10 minutes of playing because of the creepy music, random voices and noises, and of course visuals which I will not spoil. If you turn your sound off completely though, it doesn't phase me one bit. So basically, if you are chicken♥♥♥♥♥♥then you should turn off your sound so you can focus on the main objective instead of focusing on what pair of underwear you need to wash from playing this. In all seriousness though, I would only reccomend someone who has a strong stomach since most of the game is quite gory and if dissassembled body parts freak you out then you shouldn't even be playing this game. I would like to add is that this game is medium length which I don't mind. I wish it was slightly longer but you can only do so much with a story and a horror game. Something to also add, this game has medium to hard difficulty puzzles which some had taken me days to figure out. So if you are one to rush and add cheats to the game well you are out of luck buddy because there are no cheats except for walkthroughs on the game online, and you must have patience. I would rate this game a 8/10 and reccomend anyone 16+

content:
Posted: December 29, 2010
												This was one of the most intense horror games I have ever played through.  Rarely does a game make me jump, but this managed to do it many times.  The atmosphere is chilling, to the point where you are afraid to even move to the next area, lest you come across a beast that will tear you to pieces in seconds.  The use of darkness causing your character's insanity to warp the reality you are perceiving was a great idea.  The light is your only friend here.  It is a short but thrilling ride, but I feel the price reflects that.  If you're a fan of horror/survival games, I can't recommend this one enough.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 3, 2016
												I'll keep this short and sweet.  Amnesia: The Dark Descent is without a doubt one of the greatest horror experiences you can have.  The story is pieced together by the main character Daniel who awoke with amnesia and after that you begin understanding his objective throughout the game.  Gathering information on this beautifully crafted and immersive little world involves finding notes scattered in all sorts of places.  Exploration is important.This is not your traditional horror game where you can fight back.  Your only means of survival are hiding, running or distracting enemies then progressing to the next area which is done seamlessly thanks to the  automatic save system.  While you explore you will encounter instances where puzzles must be solved in order to progress.  You solve them by interacting with objects in the world, be they rocks, boxes, gears, etc.  Some puzzles are simple, others require a little more thinking outside the box.  Keep in mind that if the solution is too obvious, it's actually very likely the correct one!    You can also throw objects to cause distractions.  All of these things combined makes for an incredibly immersive experience.  You have two forms of life, standard health and sanity.  If either one depletes entirely you're dead.  Thankfully you can find items that will heal both of these. You start off with a lantern and must search for fuel to keep it lit.  Another means to help you are tinderboxes which are used on various light sources such as torches.   I don't really have a negative thing to say about this.  It's unique, terrifying, creative, immersive, gorgeous, with a brilliantly written story.  This is one of those games that will age greatly.  Oh, and one more thing, there is only one way to play this: in complete darkness with a set of decent headphones and the volume cranked.

content:
Posted: September 15, 2015
												Amnesia: The Dark Descent is one of the best horror-survival games I've ever played. The ominous ambiance, the opressive feeling of helplessness, rotting decay, and sudden rush of adrenaline... it's even better than years ago, when it scared the heck out of me. What scared me the most back then, is that you're trying to be calm in your darkened room with your headphones and wet hands grabbing the mouse, when something makes you jump and race away. You NEED this game, not only because it's superbly designed, but for the originality of it, in a genre that has become rather dull. The graphics have not aged well, but the complexity of the game remains just the same. It took me two years to finish it the first time, even when  it's a long game... but because I couldn't bear the scares quite often. This time... I'm ready.

content:
Posted: June 22, 2012
												This game is a buggy peice of♥♥♥♥♥♥ which randomly crashes upon switching maps, It's easy to randomly clip out of bounds (I managed to on my first playthrough) and items can often get stuck or go through walls. These are just some of the numerous bugs and glitches found in this game.The options menu is kinda good and it runs decent on bad computers. But one problem is that the gamma settings are for the entire system which means that if you have 2 monitors and put the gamma on the highest setting, the other monitor will look terrible.But the bugs aside this is about the best survival horror game you can find as I'm typing this. The first person view and making you not be able to fight back make this game really tense and scary if you are in a situation where the monster spots you and you must run. The environment, ambience and of course the soundtrack is mostly what makes the game scary. It's not actually the monster itself that is so scary, it's the premonition of him being around every corner you see that makes the game scary.Overall i would recommend this game to people that liked Outlast because of the similarities and also to people that just enjoy being scared.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 15, 2014
												This is by far the scariest game I've ever played. The atmosphere in this game is amazing, from the castle setting to the superb audio and the constant fear of what you'll see around the next corner. I made sure to play this game mainly after dark with headphones and I am glad I did. It took me something like a year of on and off playing to finish the game, as playing the game  was mentally unsettling at times and difficult to garner the willpower to keep playing. That's OK though because that is exactly what I want from a horror game. There were many times when I squealed out loud in terror and even developed a bit of a sweat. I highly recommend this game and recommend playing at night with headphones for an optimal experience. This game makes me truely concerned of how horror games in VR are going to affect people. Good luck.

content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
												Amnesia has a special something that most games fail to acheive. That is what you become aware of almost as soon as you finish the game. The only way I could possibly describe the game once I finished was... Wow... Just wow... The game is probobly the example of what a horror game should be for all the indie creators and AAA developers out there. However, what does this game achieve in?To start off, we must discuss the story. The story is what makes up a game for me as a gamer. Game has bad story, its a bad game. There has only been a handful of games that go against this, but even still, those handful don't match the rest. However, Amnesia's story is phenomenal and a lot darker then you anticipate. When I entered, I thought this game was going to have a very gothic story (which it did) but did not see the grisly scenes of torture coming up on the plot. Even if this is all told in flashbacks and distrubing hallucinations, it does not take away from the fact the story is messed up. YOU WILL REGRET TRYING TO REMEMBER WHAT YOU FORGOT. Daniel says to himself in the very beginning "I choose to forget" and you'll see why sure enough. To put it simply, do not doubt for a moment this game's story will get to you.Onto Gameplay, it's a straight through adventure with puzzles and terror thrown in the mix. The game is actually pretty open believe it or not, not Minecraft kind of open but a open where some of the rooms have little purpose but to be there. (Which is what I believe Amnesia: Machine for Pigs I lacking, but that's not the point). The castle is a fun place to explore and the puzzles why can have little things you might miss, truly are not frustrating. If you want a frustrating horror puzzle game, go to Anna:Extended Edition. While that was not a bad game at all, the puzzles get very annoying. Amnesia however masters the right balance of puzzles and terror and really make a good game out of it. Part of the gameplay as well, is as you might expect hiding, running, and screaming. I did not die much during the game, which is a good thing, but the moments I ran and hid sent chills rushing through my spine and got the adreniline pumping. However, I'll discuss that in scarinessThe game is scary, every moment is scary, this game is the scariest game out there. You will not know what to expect, and some of the areas will truly scare you. I got scared several times and panicked at little and big things, the game's atmopshere really prepares you for this game. If you don't believe me, do the "immersion" the game discusses at the beginning and do just that. You will surely have a heart attack... (I suggest calling 911 before playing the game, so in the eight minutes that it takes for them to arrive, you'll have to wait little)The last thing I need to discuss is the Audio and Graphics. The graphics look great, I have to say, maybe not what everyone else seems to find "great" these days but they are good. There were only two moments where I got a buggy graphic or thought "They could have made this better" but truly its good. The game was also made in 2010 when we still were just starting to improve graphics, so I have no complaints. The Audio however is what is really important to discuss, the Audio is what makes the game scary. The whole game I played with headphones, though it made me cower in fear and suffer serious mental issues, I don't regret a thing. There is a certain thing that the game does with it's audio, that just makes it so good. You don't even need a screen for some of the audio to send shivers down your spine. It sticks with you far after the game is done and when you hear that Grunt or Brute's cry of anger you will fear for your life.Overall, the game is excellent. Do not miss out on this game. It is one of the best game I have ever played in my life and sure as heck the best horror game.Story 9/10Gameplay 9/10Scariness 10/10Graphic & Audio 9/10Overall: 9/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 15, 2012
												I rate this game #1 constipation reliever. The whole dark atmosphere and the fact that there is always something lurking around the corner is very paranoia inducing. There is also the fact that there is absolutely NO way to defend yourself; running away and hiding is the only key to survival. Keeping your sanity, as well as your health, is a big factor in gameplay. Your character suffers from nyctophobia (the fear of darkness) which, as a result, causes your character to go insane when staying in the darkness for a prolonged amount of time. This sets a new difficulty for playing the game as you are easier to detect and movement becomes much harder while in this state. However, staying in light sources will make it easier for them to find you... I HIGHLY recommend this game to anyone looking for a thrill, alone or with friends. I also suggest playing in darkness with a headset on for maximum effects. This game is NOT for the faint of heart; do not play with winning as your goal.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 9, 2011
												What can be said about Amnesia that hasn't already been said? Rather than attempt to quantify what makes Amnesia one of the most popular horror games to date, I'll just say that if you're looking for scares that are actually scary, look no further.Amnesia is a horror game with inventory puzzles and an odd little sanity mechanic I like to call "hide and go soil yourself". While my experience with other horror games has been limited, I can say without a doubt that Amnesia may provide one of the most visceral experiences you have ever gone through in a video game.Amnesia is an absolute joy to play with your friends. If you can manage the time, play through it once on your own, then invite your friends to play it and watch them experience it for the first time. Amnesia is the only game that I have found able to inspire such a feeling of well-meaning spite towards your friends. The kind of spite where you want them to go through the same horrors you did just to see who has better bladder control.When you're done with Amnesia, and you've plumbed the depths of any of the interesting custom levels made by the community, the previous, though unrelated story-wise, Penumbra series by the same developers can wring out a few more decent scares. Just make sure your heart can take it before purchasing.

content:
Posted: June 26, 2016
												Pros:-Can use surrounding objects to your advantage-Very Scary-Difficult, Challenging-Amazing Soundtrack-Interesting gameplay mechanics (Sanity Meter, can't stay in the dark long enough)-Levels are non - linear, which makes it feel more ordinary (Buildings aren't built in a linear fashion, a corridor would have mutliple rooms on the sides, etc).-Amazing atmosphereCons:-Monsters don't wander around for a long time, they spawn when the player walks in a certain area. There isn't a set number of Monsters that roam / patrol the area, which would make it so that you would have to spend a certain amount of time in an area.-Can't pick up candles / monsters are somewhat immune to objects (I can't hit a shovel very hard to stun a brute).-Game is somewhat short (They should have added some more levels / more rooms to explore).In other words, 8 / 10.

content:
Posted: January 18
												Amnesia is a pants sh*tting experience (nearly) throughout the whole game. It revived survival horror and brought it into the mainstream......however......once you discover the pattern behind the monster encounters, it's over. As in, the tension disappears and the fear factor becomes non-existent. In addition, the main protagonist's reactions are way overdone. He gets a seizure and hyperventilates each time a book falls off the shelf. It's not scary, it destroys immersion and makes the protagonist seem like a total wuss, especially when my own reaction to said book is a resounding 'meh'. I recommend it still since, other than horror, it can be an entertaining adventure game.For those curious, I will write about the pattern down below.*SPOILERS*It's not hard to discover the pattern, unfortunately.- The monster spawns are entirely scripted. They spawn very often once you take a puzzle item or solve a puzzle. Rarely when you enter a room.- To prevent from being killed, close the door to the room the puzzle or item are in before doing what you need to do. When the monster spawns, it starts attacking the door and gives you time to hide.- To hide, just break the line of sight. You don't even have to enter a dark area.- Keep being hidden until the monster music stops playing. Once this occurs, the monster literally despawned, i.e. it vanished, disappeared. You can now run around freely until a next monster spawns.There are one or two exceptions where the monster is already there, has a defined patrol route, and does not despawn.

												There aren't many horror games that and truly make you feel hesitant to play them not because they're bad games but because they truly keep you on edge. Amnesia: The Dark Descent is one of those games, and yes, I admit that I completely broke down at one point for fear that a monster would show up and slice up my back.Unfortunately, if you think about it for a while, the monsters become quite predictable and easy to avoid. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 16, 2011
												Why is Amnesia so fantastic? It breaches the mindless, scripted scares that encompass other modern horror games today through a unique approach. This game throws you into a dark world where you remember nothing about where you are or why you are there, except that there is an unknown shadow chasing you as you try to decipher your purpose. Sitting in the dark causes you to hallucinate and slowly lose your mind, and you can die simply from looking at a monster for too long. The fear of the unknown, immersive ambience, and tense motifs are what scare the hell out of anyone attempting to play this game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 15, 2015
												Amnesia: The Dark Descent is one of the best horror-survival games I've ever played. The ominous ambiance, the opressive feeling of helplessness, rotting decay, and sudden rush of adrenaline... it's even better than years ago, when it scared the heck out of me. What scared me the most back then, is that you're trying to be calm in your darkened room with your headphones and wet hands grabbing the mouse, when something makes you jump and race away. You NEED this game, not only because it's superbly designed, but for the originality of it, in a genre that has become rather dull. The graphics have not aged well, but the complexity of the game remains just the same. It took me two years to finish it the first time, even when  it's a long game... but because I couldn't bear the scares quite often. This time... I'm ready.

content:
Posted: April 21, 2012
												If you want to be scared ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, this is the game. The ambiance and mood can be frightening, even when there is no immenent danger. Play in the dark, with headphones, alone. You will see. The main story line had medium replay value, but many many MANY custom stories are available which can be just as scary, or scarier. Endless fun and scares to be had here. If you want it to be less hardcore, you can join a skype call with your friends, share your screen, and let them help you out and enjoy your screams. Having a friendly voice in the background lessens the fear factor. Overall, I give this game an A++ for pulling the purpose off well, having little to no glitches, and having ( nearly ) endless free custom stories.

content:
Posted: October 11, 2013
												Anyone learning how to make games should play Amnesia the Dark Descent. I say this because I can't really think of many other games that are so masterfully atmospheric. Yes the game is scary, hur da dur everyone knows that. What I love so much about Dark Descent is that its scares are not just cheap jump scares and sensationalist set pieces. It is intelligent in how it goes about scaring you, resorting to audio and a dynamic between light and dark to really bring you in. Amnesia will make you feel terror in a very raw sense that few other games can come close to. Amnesia is a hallmark of the horror genre and arguable a hallmark of video games alltogether.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 29, 2010
												This was one of the most intense horror games I have ever played through.  Rarely does a game make me jump, but this managed to do it many times.  The atmosphere is chilling, to the point where you are afraid to even move to the next area, lest you come across a beast that will tear you to pieces in seconds.  The use of darkness causing your character's insanity to warp the reality you are perceiving was a great idea.  The light is your only friend here.  It is a short but thrilling ride, but I feel the price reflects that.  If you're a fan of horror/survival games, I can't recommend this one enough.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 19, 2015
												Disturbing, engrossing, and challenging, The Dark Descent is both a harrowing horror experience and a decently well realized narrative with careful attention paid to nailing the pacing subtleties.Gameplay is simple and has quality stealth mechanics and sound cues. The adventure game-y puzzles and a plethora of crafting tasks can get a little tiresome by the final strech, but I never lost the investment to beat the game. The experience begins itself perfectly, calling the player to persevere and conquer the ever consuming darkness and NOT be afraid (although you will be).Play it with the lights off and headphones. It's a great ride.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 5, 2015
												Rejuvenating survival horror. Perfect, endlessly unsettling sound design. Horrifying environments. Pure chilling Lovecraftian narrative told and unearthed in a consistently engaging manner. Puzzles that are simple enough to not become frustrating and challenging enough to not feel like pointless busywork. An unshakeable feeling of being chased and even in the dingiest corners being constantly out in the open and exposed to danger. Hiding from monsters that more often than not aren't there, abusing every inch of your imagination, and when they are there delivering terrifying sequences of frantic escape slamming doors behind you and terrified hiding cowering into walls desperately trying not to be seen, having to balance attempts at avoiding them with your dwindling sanity in the dark. Leaping from box to box in a flooded room avoiding the invisible creature that waits in the water, and the panicked rush to safety when you inevitably slip and hear the splashing rapidly approaching behind you. Lighting, sanity and "flight not fight" mechanics that have impacted so much in the five years since its release, making it hard to imagine the horror landscape of the 2010s without it. The defining horror game of the decade so far.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 27, 2015
												Everything that needs be said about this game has already been said. It is a fantastically frightening experience for those that get immersed in horror games and even after countless imitators, it still stands out as the best example of its particular style. Cracks may begin to show in the mechanics if you play it like a regular game, and it requires a certain commitment of mind and focus to have the intended effect, but for those into this kind of thing, it will always be one of the scariest games ever made.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 10, 2014
												This is such a fantastic game - even though I'm having problems with it, no matter how many times I die to monsters (or end up getting stuck inside a room) I just want to keep playing. In fact, I'm doing a series of highlights videos on my Youtube channel where I'm playing through this pretty much completely blind. I'm not picking up any notes or journals or diaries; I'm not reading anything, and I'm still having a blast with it when I'm wandering around not knowing what to do. I guess that's just another great thing about this game; they managed to make a coherent story using only flashbacks, so that even without reading any of the important stuff I still kind of know why I'm doing what I'm doing. I'm even looking forward to finishing this first playthrough so I can go back on my own and read everything up, pick up all the details I missed and see how much that changes the story.This is the first part of my series if you want to check it out: 


YouTube™ Video: Amnesia: The Dark Descent - Let's Play Highlights - Part 1 

			Views: 34		

			Wherein I skip every note, journal, memento, and diary while playing Amnesia: The Dark Descent. If you enjoyed the video, leave a like - it really helps!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 9, 2016
												Amnesia: The Dark Descent is a revivification of the atmospheric horror game. Unable to fight the abominations that stalk you, Amnesia leaves you alone in a gritty atmospheric, slowly turning horrific, setting that pushes you toward finding the answers to your ailment, Amnesia. The game focuses on a few game-play mechanics such as health, mental health (though I believe is called insanity in the game), and finding what are essentially keys for the next zone (though are often items and puzzles) while for the most part being actively stalked by monsters. Some of the most notable elements of the game-play are the mental health meter and its gripping pacing. The mental health in the game involves your ability to stay in the light and avoid gazing at monsters for too long. The second being probably the most important feature. Once the unknown becomes the known it becomes a lot less frightful, so having a game-play mechanic that punishes the unknown becoming known it incredibly smart and well done and it is sufficient enough to last almost the entire game (the later areas somewhat abandon this concept, and it becomes a lot less scary for doing so). Until the end of the game it does a good job of pacing areas of horror and peace, though unannounced to the player, and never once did I feel cheated by the monsters. Overall I would suggest Amnesia to anyone who is looking for a dark, gripping, and atmospheric horror game that will last you a couple of days (approximately 8 hours of content).

content:
Posted: January 23, 2014
												If you enjoy Horror games then this is the Game for you.The StoryPlaced in a Midevil Setting Daniel has been taken to Castle Beninburg by the Owner Alexander, a insane killer who drugs his victums with an Amnesia Potion. From there Daniel finds out the truth of Castle Beninburg and he takes an Amnesia Potion and runs away to find Alexander. Along the way a monster chases him but as soon as the Amnesia Potion starts to kick in the monster is blocked off by a celing crash and from there your adventure begins.The GameplayAmnesia: TDD is a First Person Horror game and uses it well with the gameplay. You can pick up items to use them later and pick up objects to take them with you even if they have no use. There is also a sanity use in this game. Sanity is well used in this game. You lose sanity by being in the Dark. You also lose sanity from other things like finding human bones in a unsuspecting spot like a cabnet in a Desk. Looking at the monsters also drain your sanity. Unlike other games you can't attack the monsters. Things like stone hammers are not used as combat tools. Insted you have to use your wits to escape the Monsters. Like for example the classic Hide in the closet. You can also try to out run the monsters too. Getting back to the sanity you can gain it back by being in the light, using sanity potions and other stuff.OtherFrictional Games also created the Penumbra Series, So this isn't there first horror game. But it's the first where you can't attack.VerdictAmnesia is a Great game that even spawned a sequal which i have not yet played. Saddly Custom Storys are not availble in the sequal and that means no using the edited Amnesia engine you got to use the original but we're talking about A: TDD so what is my score10/10GET THIS GAME OR GET OUT!!!For Realz get the game... i'll give you a free stephano (Lie)

content:
Posted: July 5, 2011
												I'll be very honest with it. Out of all the horror games I have played so far, this is the only TRUE survival horror. Games like Dead Space and others, they focus on ACTION as much as they focus on environment or atmosphere. But in this game, Amnesia, you get NO weapons. There is no action. The only weapon you get in this game are your feet that you can only use to RUN for your life. Trust me, this game will never scare you with high volume sounds (like other horror games do). It's the atmosphere, environment and situation that scares you in this game. If you like horror games, give it a try, I am sure you will like it. It will change the way of your thinking about horror games.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 20, 2014
												The infamous Amnesia. Driven by a dark and twisted storyline, backed by a soundtrack that is bound to give you the chills, Amnesia is everything you could ask for in a horror game.Introduction:Amnesia is a first person survival horror game set in a dark and mysterious castle environment.The plot takes place in 1893 where a young man from London, Daniel, finds himself awakened in the great halls of the Prussian Brennenburg Castle with no recollections of himself, his past or his current purpose. The only objects that guide Daniel in his journey are hand-written notes that he has written to himself, such as the one he finds in the beginning of the game. Controls and Gameplay:The most powerful feature in the game is the absence of items, such as weapons and armor. You are alone and defenseless. Only equipped with a lantern, run by a limited supply of fuel, your goal is to explore and uncover the dark secrets of castle Brenneburg. This is a core feature of the game, as it makes your journey through the castle perilous and terrifying.  Aside from the traditional health bar, your character has a sanity meter. Sanity is reduced if you spend too much time in the dark, and loss of sanity will progressively make your screen indistinct and blurry. Puzzles and other obstructions are also present in the game. They are, however, not difficult and are sometimes a more than welcome "time-out" in the intense horror, while at other times they participate in making the game more hectic and intense. In terms of control, they are working as intended and do not obstruct the player in his quest through the dark.Graphics:The graphics in the game are slightly dated. This is not a huge minus, as the graphics actually enhance the intense sensation of dread that is omnipresent in the game. Sound:The soundtrack subliminally emphasizes the mood of the game. It intensifies frightening moments and sooths you in safe zones. It sometimes disappears completely, leaving your character's frantically beating heart as the only sound...Replayability:As a consequence of the game's linear storyline, multiple playthroughs are not of interest. Once you have played through the game once, you have seen most of the content there is. Conclusion:Amnesia: The Dark Descent is a unique first person horror game driven by its compelling story and simple gameplay. Experience the intense and thrilling game equipped with only a lantern and your courage and uncover the dark secrets of Castle Brennenburg.  Recommendable: 10/10

												Amnesia: The Dark Descent is a revivification of the atmospheric horror game. Unable to fight the abominations that stalk you, Amnesia leaves you alone in a gritty atmospheric, slowly turning horrific, setting that pushes you toward finding the answers to your ailment, Amnesia. The game focuses on a few game-play mechanics such as health, mental health (though I believe is called insanity in the game), and finding what are essentially keys for the next zone (though are often items and puzzles) while for the most part being actively stalked by monsters. Some of the most notable elements of the game-play are the mental health meter and its gripping pacing. The mental health in the game involves your ability to stay in the light and avoid gazing at monsters for too long. The second being probably the most important feature. Once the unknown becomes the known it becomes a lot less frightful, so having a game-play mechanic that punishes the unknown becoming known it incredibly smart and well done and it is sufficient enough to last almost the entire game (the later areas somewhat abandon this concept, and it becomes a lot less scary for doing so). Until the end of the game it does a good job of pacing areas of horror and peace, though unannounced to the player, and never once did I feel cheated by the monsters. Overall I would suggest Amnesia to anyone who is looking for a dark, gripping, and atmospheric horror game that will last you a couple of days (approximately 8 hours of content).

content:
Posted: June 26, 2016
												Pros:-Can use surrounding objects to your advantage-Very Scary-Difficult, Challenging-Amazing Soundtrack-Interesting gameplay mechanics (Sanity Meter, can't stay in the dark long enough)-Levels are non - linear, which makes it feel more ordinary (Buildings aren't built in a linear fashion, a corridor would have mutliple rooms on the sides, etc).-Amazing atmosphereCons:-Monsters don't wander around for a long time, they spawn when the player walks in a certain area. There isn't a set number of Monsters that roam / patrol the area, which would make it so that you would have to spend a certain amount of time in an area.-Can't pick up candles / monsters are somewhat immune to objects (I can't hit a shovel very hard to stun a brute).-Game is somewhat short (They should have added some more levels / more rooms to explore).In other words, 8 / 10.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 9, 2011
												What can be said about Amnesia that hasn't already been said? Rather than attempt to quantify what makes Amnesia one of the most popular horror games to date, I'll just say that if you're looking for scares that are actually scary, look no further.Amnesia is a horror game with inventory puzzles and an odd little sanity mechanic I like to call "hide and go soil yourself". While my experience with other horror games has been limited, I can say without a doubt that Amnesia may provide one of the most visceral experiences you have ever gone through in a video game.Amnesia is an absolute joy to play with your friends. If you can manage the time, play through it once on your own, then invite your friends to play it and watch them experience it for the first time. Amnesia is the only game that I have found able to inspire such a feeling of well-meaning spite towards your friends. The kind of spite where you want them to go through the same horrors you did just to see who has better bladder control.When you're done with Amnesia, and you've plumbed the depths of any of the interesting custom levels made by the community, the previous, though unrelated story-wise, Penumbra series by the same developers can wring out a few more decent scares. Just make sure your heart can take it before purchasing.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2010
												This was one of the most intense horror games I have ever played through.  Rarely does a game make me jump, but this managed to do it many times.  The atmosphere is chilling, to the point where you are afraid to even move to the next area, lest you come across a beast that will tear you to pieces in seconds.  The use of darkness causing your character's insanity to warp the reality you are perceiving was a great idea.  The light is your only friend here.  It is a short but thrilling ride, but I feel the price reflects that.  If you're a fan of horror/survival games, I can't recommend this one enough.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 1, 2014
												Amnesia is easily the scariest game I've ever played, and I'm a big fan of horror games. Games like Resident Evil are a lot of fun, but barely manage to scare me. Also, what's up with Slender being like the standard for a good horror game. Slender is scary once, the first time you see Slenderman. After that you're just wandering through the woods while the same guy chases you. It's good for a free horror game, yet some people think it's the scariest game ever, but it doesn't come close to Amnesia. Anyway, Amnesia scares you in so many ways. Not only are the enemies chasing you incredibly disturbing, there are lots of kind of less obvious, but incredibly scary, moments. Once I went into a room, saw a cage with a dead body in it hanging from the ceiling, and later when I returned to the room it was gone... The story is also very creepy if you pay attention to the notes you find. If you don't use an online guide, like me, the game will take you somewhere from 8-10 hours, but if you do use a guide then it shouldn't take longer than 5 or so. I actually liked their previous games, The Penumbra series, better than Amnesia in terms of gameplay, but Amnesia is much scarier.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 8, 2014
												Amnesia is probably one of my favourite games of all time and cetainly my favourite horror title of all time. The game itself plays very well and provides a very good atmosphere and mood. The enemies are always dangerous and always pose a threat to the player since you only have the capacity to outrun them over short distances and long distances will result in you being caught and likely killed. The games scare factor varies based on the player I myself didn't find it scary however it was tense and immersive and I enjoyed the experiece a lot.The games visuals are rather dated however, the lighting could use some touching up and some of the textures look as if they are from a very old game. However this didn't seem to ruin the immersion for me as its possible to interact with almost every object within the game world such a levers, candles, torches, barrels, crates and books to name a few, even those objects that aren't relevant are able to be interected with. This adds an extra layer of depth to the gameplay as it gets the player thinking about what is needed to complete certain sections and puzzles within the game. I was also quite impressed with the storyline and the way it was told as the notes system and being able to read into it by picking them up throughout the game allows for various interpretations of the story and also allows players to connect with it at their own pace. The average amount of play time it takes to complete the game I feel is also worth it for the price as it is a very enjoyable time and can potentially be played through again dependent on the players view of the game. This game also incorporates a few good mechanics such as the depleting lantern oil and insanity. This adds to the difficultly and fits in with it being in the survival horror genre. It could also signficantly alter the way some players move through the game.Overall: Fantastic, 90/100

content:
Posted: June 16, 2014
												One of the best games I've ever played! My first introduction to the horror genre was "among the sleep" and after that game I wanted more! Unlike "among the sleep" this game has (for me at least) a duration of 10 hours. And ten good spent hours! At first I didn't really think it was scary, but as the game progressed it became very frightning. The puzzles are lots of times hard to solve so that was really enjoying. Then the surroundings, fantastic! I wonder what the developers used to come up with these visual FX :p because it really reminded me of my time on mushrooms. Playing HD it sometimes really makes you look around you (in your own room) to check if it isn't the game but you ; )Then the sounds and music! as a composer I greatly admire the work and care they have put into the entire audio experience. If you have a sub, turn it on! The sounds they used for various things really attributed to the overall experience. But it’s not just the sound or the visuals, but the way they are programmed and put together! But I won’t go into detail, because I’m afraid it might spoil your experience of the game.Then the story… great story! It really takes you quite a while to wrap your head around it. And the more you know, the scarier it becomes. And my last comment is that this game has some really high quality fright moments. If I would get a euro for every time I didn’t see something coming and scare the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of me, I could go out to dinner for a week :pSo I really recommend it! This is a piece of art and will keep you thinking even when not playing it. So have fun! And get ready to poop your pants!
